headline: Applied Materials Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2010
componenttextpreview: Welcome to the Applied Materials Fiscal 2010 First Quarter Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] Please note that today's call will contain forward-looking statements, which are all statements other than those of historical fact, including statements r
componenttext: Welcome to the Applied Materials Fiscal 2010 First Quarter Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] Please note that today's call will contain forward-looking statements, which are all statements other than those of historical fact, including statements regarding Applied's performance, growth opportunities, cost reduction activities, strategic positions, markets and Q2 and fiscal year 2010 outlooks, as well as industry outlooks. All forward-looking statements are subject to known and unknown risks and uncertainties that could cause actual results to differ materially from those expressed or implied by such statements. Information concerning these risk factors is contained in today's earnings press release and in the company's filings with the SEC. Forward-looking statements are based on information as of February 17, 2010 and the company assumes no obligation to update such statements. Today's call also contains non-GAAP financial measures. Reconciliations of the non-GAAP measures to GAAP measures are contained in today's earnings release or in the Financial Highlights slides, which are on the Investor page of our website at appliedmaterials.com. I would now like to turn the conference over to Michael Sullivan, Vice President of Investor Relations. Please go ahead, sir.

headline: Applied Materials Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2010
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Marcelo, and good afternoon. Joining me today are Mike Splinter, our Chairman and CEO; George Davis, our Chief Financial Officer; and Joe Sweeney, our General Counsel and Corporate Secretary.Today, we'll discuss the results for our first quarte
componenttext: Thank you, Marcelo, and good afternoon. Joining me today are Mike Splinter, our Chairman and CEO; George Davis, our Chief Financial Officer; and Joe Sweeney, our General Counsel and Corporate Secretary.Today, we'll discuss the results for our first quarter, which ended on January 31. Our earnings release was issued at 1:05 Pacific Time and you could find a copy on Business Wire and on our website, appliedmaterials.com. Mike Splinter will be off the call with comments on the business environment and our strategies. George will follow and discuss our financial performance for Q1 and our expectations for Q2 and the rest of the year. We'll then open the call for your questions. Before we begin, I have a quick calendar announcement. Applied will hold its 2010 Analyst Meeting in New York City on the afternoon of March 30 local time. We hope to see you at the meeting and we'll have a live webcast and replay for anyone who won't be able to join us in person. We'll be sure to provide you at further details about the event over the next few weeks. And with that, I'd like to hand the call over to Mike Splinter.

headline: Applied Materials Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2010
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Mike, and welcome to today's call. Applied generated strong growth in our first quarter, led by our Silicon Systems Group, which grew net sales by nearly 50%. Our business momentum continues and we're raising our company-wide fiscal year sales out
componenttext: Thanks, Mike, and welcome to today's call. Applied generated strong growth in our first quarter, led by our Silicon Systems Group, which grew net sales by nearly 50%. Our business momentum continues and we're raising our company-wide fiscal year sales outlook to growth of more than 50%. We completed the acquisition of Semitool, giving us new growth opportunities in semiconductor equipment and leadership in advanced packaging. We also took actions to improve our efficiency and bring the core of our operations closer to more of our customers. The steep ramp in SSG challenged our manufacturing and field support operations, and I'd like to thank our teams and suppliers for working especially hard to meet our customers' needs.I'll now comment on each of our businesses. We now expect SSG sales to more than double in fiscal 2010. We've raised our wafer fab equipment spending projection to a range of $21 billion to $23 billion for the calendar year, and we view 2010 as just the first year of a strong investment cycle. Memory prices remain high, encouraging customers to invest in the next generation of technology. In 2010, bit demand for memory is expected to outpace supply. Foundries are investing aggressively for their transition to 32 nanometers and for capacity additions at 45 nanometers. We believe the next phase of investment will be driven by DRAM technology transitions along with capacity expansions in both flash memory and foundry. Customers are also discussing plans for new fabs, which should lead to increased equipment spending in 2011.We expect this year to have strong competitive gains, with more than two points of share growth across SSG. We expect Applied's net sales to more than double in the calendar year, reflecting market growth, share gains and favorable memory customer exposure. Increased memory spending is also the catalyst for our Brightfield system, giving us the opportunity to gain five points a share in the nearly $1 billion wafer defect inspection market. In radical inspection, we expanded our installed base with another strategic placement at a major foundry. In CMP, our new Reflexion GT is gaining traction as it allows customers to greatly reduce the costs of consumables. And our new Astra laser anneal system is enabling advanced transistors at 32 nanometers and beyond. In PVD and CVD, we're on track to gain share leading edge where steps are being added in metal gates, silicides, gap fill and packaging. We're very pleased with the progress of our Semitool acquisition. We've been collaborating with Semitool in advanced packaging for years, allowing us to hit the ground running with a suite of products to serve a growing market, which is expected to reach nearly $800 million by 2012. For example, we expect to have at least 25 charger PVD systems installed for packaging in 2010 In AGS, the number of semiconductor tools under contract in Asia grew by 20% year-over-year. We're focusing on additional service and spares growth in the region, which is expected to drive 75% of all new wafer capacity. The Display industry sees strong demand in LCD TVs, particularly in China. High factory utilization of around 90% is leading customers to plan for new capacity. We expect Display equipment spending to grow by more than 60% over approximately the next 12 months. Looking ahead, we expect Applied's orders to increase driven by higher investments in Gen 8.5 capacity over the cycle. We've ramped our manufacturing facility in Taiwan and maintained our system lead times despite this transition. Our Gen. 10 CVD systems are now proven in production and we're ready to ramp this next generation of glass size.In solar, worldwide PVD PV installations are expected to be up 50% year-over-year, with about half of this growth in European countries outside of Germany. Module prices have absorbed the polysilicon price drops and we see price declines moderating ahead of the German FIT adjustment. In China, the government has made solar a national priority and crystal and silicon solar manufacturers are responding by boosting capacity. We expect 5 to 7 gigawatts of incremental capacity additions in China this year, which represents a near doubling from '09. Globally, we see the possibility of up to 9 gigawatts of capacity additions. Solar CapEx should exceed $4 billion this calendar year and factory utilization across the industry is reported to be around 50%, and today's aggressive capacity additions could lead to oversupply and a reduction in investment plans. The strong solar capacity expansion in China has been a positive for our Crystal and Silicon business. We achieved sign-offs for our new Baccini Esatto Technology in the quarter as double printing became established at multiple customers. And we expect our Baccini Cell Systems to gain 3 points of metallization share in 2010.Turning to SunFab, we achieved sign-off at two new lines during the quarter, bringing the total to nine. The price declines in crystal and silicon modules have exerted margin pressure at some of our thin film customers. In some cases, lowering their demand and factory utilization to very low levels. We made further progress in driving SunFab module efficiency and cost reductions to help customers be more competitive. Two customers announced large development projects this quarter and our customers now have 30 megawatts of modules installed, providing field performance data to demonstrate the capabilities of our technology.I'd like to comment briefly on the recent events in Korea. As you know, several of our employees were charged with improperly using customer confidential information. We are working with the Korean prosecutor and also conducting our own investigation in order to better understand the facts in this situation. Applied has strict policies and procedures designed to protect our customers' confidential information. We are also committed to upholding high ethical standards in all of our business dealings. And for more than 40 years, we have developed a history of outstanding, intellectual property protection, which is at the heart of our company's values. The conduct described by the charges is not consistent with either our policies or the great work performed by Applied's talented and dedicated employees. It is important to note that Applied Materials has not been charged in this case. Our focus at this time is on being close to our customers, helping them to meet a steep ramp and ensuring that the strategic relationships and trust that we built over many years remain strong. In closing, our goal is to leave the industry in our core semiconductor market, expand our opportunities in Display and services and drive new growth in Energy and Environmental Solutions. We're also significantly improving our efficiency and effectiveness to deliver outstanding profitability for the long term. I'll now hand the call over to George for more details on our financial results and targets. George?

headline: Applied Materials Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2010
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Mike, and good afternoon to everyone joining us today. Applied's financial performance improved in a strengthening business environment with results in the upper end of our target range led by strong operating performance in our Silicon Systems
componenttext: Thank you, Mike, and good afternoon to everyone joining us today. Applied's financial performance improved in a strengthening business environment with results in the upper end of our target range led by strong operating performance in our Silicon Systems Group. Applied's orders were up 33% sequentially, driven almost entirely by SSG. Net sales increased 21% to $1.85 billion, with growth in all segments except Display. We reported non-GAAP net income of $179 million or $0.13 per share. Our GAAP results included restructuring and acquisition charges, along with investment impairments that together reduced earnings by $0.07 per share. As a reminder, our non-GAAP results and guidance now include stock-based compensation.Our backlog increased by $200 million to $2.9 billion in line with order growth. The net positive backlog adjustment of $79 million was driven primarily by the Semitool acquisition. Please note that except for ending balances, the Semitool acquisition will be included in our results beginning in Q2 reported on a one month lag through the end of this fiscal year. The company generated operating cash flow of $367 million or 20% of sales. We ended the quarter with cash and investments of $3.2 billion, a reduction from Q4 of just under $70 million, despite spending $323 million for Semitool and $80 million for dividends.Turning to spending, operating expenses grew as expected and included $24 million in acquisition and legal costs that were not in our November outlook. Our non-GAAP operating expenses grew during the quarter by approximately $90 million, primarily due to the elimination of certain temporary savings, impacting base and variable compensation, and the absence of approximately $20 million in favorable adjustments in our Q4 numbers. During the quarter, we took restructuring charges of $104 million and realized $12 million in net savings from our longer-term cost initiatives. In the balance of the year, we expect our operating expenses to be between $520 million and $540 million per quarter. This run rate includes $25 million in quarterly spending for Semitool, the elimination of shutdowns and incremental spending to support the steep business ramp, partially offset by ongoing cost initiatives.We remain focused on our longer-term initiatives to enhance the company's Pan-Asia supply chain, to integrate our sales teams into the business units and to improve our back office and IT infrastructure for more efficient transaction processing. These programs are still expected to deliver $450 million of annualized cost savings by the end of our second fiscal quarter of 2011. We expect these benefits to be back-end loaded due to the intensity of the ramp.Beginning in Q1, we moved certain costs associated with sales and marketing and variable compensation adjustments into the operating segments. This treatment provides a clear picture of each segment's performance and attains to reduce each segment's operating margin by one to three points in Q1. Of course, these changes have no impact on the company's overall results. A reconciliation is provided on our website.Turning to the segments, Silicon Systems Group orders increased by 80% over Q4, with four customers accounting for over 65% of the total. Net sales in the quarter grew 48%, well above our expectations of greater than 20%. This is a very steep ramp from 2009 levels and our supply chain was challenged during the quarter to meet demand. Our customers continue to expect short lead times and just over 70% of our sales were from orders received in the quarter.  SSG operating profit of $306 million was up nearly six points from Q4, reflecting strong flow-through and some offset due to higher compensation accruals and above normal logistics and expediting costs. We see room for further margin improvement as net sales increase. In Applied Global Services, orders increased 41% of a low Q4 level and net sales were up 9% on higher fab utilization and increased wafer starts. Operating margin declined two points to 15%, primarily due to low margin refurbished systems. Display orders decreased slightly in Q1 but we expect momentum later in the year as customers remain on track for new Gen 8.5 investments. Net sales of $132 million were lower as anticipated and operating margin was down modestly to 18.9%. In EES, orders decreased 36% primarily due to declines in thin film solar. Orders for crystal and silicon solar equipment more than tripled versus Q4 on strong demand for our wafering and cell products, particularly from China. Net sales increased to $321 million driven by two SunFab sign-offs. Growth of 15% was close to our expectation of 20%. While EES reported a modest loss this quarter, we're still targeting EES to be break even on a non-GAAP basis for the year based on crystal and silicon profitability and SunFab sign-offs in the latter part of our fiscal year. Non-GAAP break even represents a $160 million improvement over 2009 and is one of the most important profit enhancement efforts for the company in 2010.Now let me talk about our expectations for the balance of the fiscal year and for Q2. While second half visibility remains limited, we are encouraged by strong demand across most of our customers and markets. As a result, we expect sales to be up by more than 50% in fiscal 2010 or by more than $2.5 billion over 2009. We expect SSG sales to be up more than 100% in fiscal 2010, reflecting growth in capital spending, improved market share and the addition of Semitool. We expect AGS sales to be up in the range of 30% this fiscal year, in line with higher utilization rates and wafer starts. We expect Display sales to be up 30% year-over-year, in line with the industry ramp. We also expect EES sales to be in the range of flat to plus or minus 10% for the fiscal year, with upside potential if crystal and silicon solar equipment demand remains strong in the second half. Our tax rate for the full year is expected to be in the range of 31% to 33%. Now I'll discuss our second quarter business environment. We remain cautious with respect to forecasting orders, particularly due to limited visibility as a result of the high turns business in SSG. Currently, our best estimate is that total company orders will be up by more than 10% quarter-over-quarter. SSG should continue to benefit from strong foundry and memory demand and sales are expected to be up by more than 25% in the quarter. AGS sales are expected to grow by more than 10%, reflecting a return to more normalized spending per wafer pass. In Display, the second quarter is shaping up to be the strongest of the fiscal year, with sales projected to more than double Q1 levels. EES sales are expected to decrease by more than 25% as growth in crystal and silicon solar equipment is more than offset by a near-term decline in thin film solar sales.We expect the company's overall net sales to be up by 15 to 25% in Q2. We also expect our non-GAAP quarterly earnings to be between $0.17 and $0.22 per share, which equates to profits growing at more than twice the rate of sales. Now Mike, let's open the call for questions.

headline: Applied Materials Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2010
componenttextpreview: Thanks, George. To help us reach as many of you as we can, please ask just one question and no more than one brief follow-up. Marcelo, let's please begin.
componenttext: Thanks, George. To help us reach as many of you as we can, please ask just one question and no more than one brief follow-up. Marcelo, let's please begin.

headline: Applied Materials Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2010
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] Our first question comes from the line of Stephen Chin with UBS.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions] Our first question comes from the line of Stephen Chin with UBS.

headline: Applied Materials Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2010
componenttextpreview: Question on the silicon guidance for the April quarter, it would suggest that Applied's still about 30% below the quarterly peak silicon sales that you saw in the 2007 cycle. And what's your view on the possibility to surpass the peak sales level during t
componenttext: Question on the silicon guidance for the April quarter, it would suggest that Applied's still about 30% below the quarterly peak silicon sales that you saw in the 2007 cycle. And what's your view on the possibility to surpass the peak sales level during this current up cycle, especially if it's driven by these foundry customers? And my follow-up question to that is similar on the Silicon segment operating margin. Do you think Applied can surpass those operating margins in 2007? And can you give us a comparable operating margin in 2007 that allocates some of these corporate overhead costs that we have something to measure Applied on?

headline: Applied Materials Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2010
componenttextpreview: I'll try to take the first part and George can take the second part. I think, at least on orders be closer to 80% than 70%, but it's really hard to tell where the peak is going to be. I think the peak would have to get something approaching $30 billion ki
componenttext: I'll try to take the first part and George can take the second part. I think, at least on orders be closer to 80% than 70%, but it's really hard to tell where the peak is going to be. I think the peak would have to get something approaching $30 billion kind of run rate in WFE. And we really haven't thought that, that's possible at this point, surpass the kind of Q2 levels of 2007. So that's kind of where we are and it's just tough to have visibility into what's going to happen in the second half as more investment broadens out from the small number of companies we're investing in semiconductor capacity today.

headline: Applied Materials Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2010
componenttextpreview: Stephen, with respect to operating profit, we kind of peaked out in Q3 '07 at just over 39%, so if you took two points off of that, at about 37%, that would've been the peak operating margin. But generally, we were operating closer to the low to mid-30s,
componenttext: Stephen, with respect to operating profit, we kind of peaked out in Q3 '07 at just over 39%, so if you took two points off of that, at about 37%, that would've been the peak operating margin. But generally, we were operating closer to the low to mid-30s, and I don't see any reason why we won't achieve those operating margins in this environment.

headline: Applied Materials Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2010
componenttextpreview: Our next question is from the line of Jim Covello with Goldman Sachs.
componenttext: Our next question is from the line of Jim Covello with Goldman Sachs.

headline: Applied Materials Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2010
componenttextpreview: I guess I'll start with flash, flash 13% of SSG orders. What's the kind of timing and trajectory that we would expect for recovery in flash orders?
componenttext: I guess I'll start with flash, flash 13% of SSG orders. What's the kind of timing and trajectory that we would expect for recovery in flash orders?

headline: Applied Materials Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, Jim, flash, as you know, 13% is well below where our run rate would be. It's a sustained kind of a bit growth of what we think could be close to 100% or so. So we're expecting that flash is going to come back in the second half of the year as the maj
componenttext: Yes, Jim, flash, as you know, 13% is well below where our run rate would be. It's a sustained kind of a bit growth of what we think could be close to 100% or so. So we're expecting that flash is going to come back in the second half of the year as the major flash producers start to invest. And so that first half, second half, we expect that when you look at it at the end of the year, flash will be close to 20% of the overall CapEx spending and wafer fab equipment spending.

headline: Applied Materials Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2010
componenttextpreview: For my follow-up, maybe for George, relative to the significant cost cuts that you guys made, are we seeing the full impact of those in the P&L kind of in the April quarter, or is there still more impact in your calendar second quarter in the back half fo
componenttext: For my follow-up, maybe for George, relative to the significant cost cuts that you guys made, are we seeing the full impact of those in the P&L kind of in the April quarter, or is there still more impact in your calendar second quarter in the back half for the year as the cost cuts flow through?

headline: Applied Materials Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2010
componenttextpreview: I think the April quarter is really where you'll see the full flow-through of any temporary cost reductions coming back in. We still had some shutdown days, normal holiday shutdown days in the first quarter. Those all go out. And then obviously, with the
componenttext: I think the April quarter is really where you'll see the full flow-through of any temporary cost reductions coming back in. We still had some shutdown days, normal holiday shutdown days in the first quarter. Those all go out. And then obviously, with the ramp of the business being stronger than we had anticipated, there's some variable comp that comes along with that, but that should be pretty much reflected in Q2.

headline: Applied Materials Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2010
componenttextpreview: Our next question is from the line of CJ Muse with Barclays Capital.
componenttext: Our next question is from the line of CJ Muse with Barclays Capital.

headline: Applied Materials Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2010
componenttextpreview: On the cost-cutting side, could you guide to gross margin and OpEx? And then digging a little bit deeper, as part of the major restructuring you talked about, can you tell us what percentage is in COGS, what percentage is in OpEx? And cognizant of that $5
componenttext: On the cost-cutting side, could you guide to gross margin and OpEx? And then digging a little bit deeper, as part of the major restructuring you talked about, can you tell us what percentage is in COGS, what percentage is in OpEx? And cognizant of that $520 million to $540 million OpEx that you're targeting in the next couple of quarters, where would that number look like when all is done around that Q2 fiscal '11 timeframe that you discussed earlier?

headline: Applied Materials Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2010
componenttextpreview: Let me just start with what we've said. We expect cost savings to be about $450 million, about $250 million of that will be OpEx. I would expect, again, the cost to be back-end loaded. So at $250 million, that's roughly $60 million a quarter. We said ther
componenttext: Let me just start with what we've said. We expect cost savings to be about $450 million, about $250 million of that will be OpEx. I would expect, again, the cost to be back-end loaded. So at $250 million, that's roughly $60 million a quarter. We said there was about $12 million a quarter already reflected in our first quarter with that adjustment. Our focus, as you know, in the near-term is really managing to the ramp, but many of the programs that we have are longer-term and we're continuing to work on those, including things like our Pan-Asia supply chain, making the organizational adjustments we've had, such as moving sales into the business units. All these things are continuing, but some of the impacts will be pushed out as we've got kind of all hands-on deck to manage the ramp.

headline: Applied Materials Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2010
componenttextpreview: On the Crystal and Silicon side, can you talk about that business a little bit on a stand-alone basis? What percentage of the EES revenues could that be in fiscal '10 and what kind of margin trajectory do you see through the fiscal year?
componenttext: On the Crystal and Silicon side, can you talk about that business a little bit on a stand-alone basis? What percentage of the EES revenues could that be in fiscal '10 and what kind of margin trajectory do you see through the fiscal year?

headline: Applied Materials Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2010
componenttextpreview: It has been about half of the revenue and order profile for EES for the last couple of years. It's probably a reasonable assumption for 2010 as well. It could be a little bit higher if you get a significant ramp in the second -- the ramp continues in the
componenttext: It has been about half of the revenue and order profile for EES for the last couple of years. It's probably a reasonable assumption for 2010 as well. It could be a little bit higher if you get a significant ramp in the second -- the ramp continues in the second half in China for crystalline silicon. And from an operating margin standpoint, it's well into the double digits now, and it's been a solid business for us.

headline: Applied Materials Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2010
componenttextpreview: Our next question is from the line of Atif Malik with Morgan Stanley.
componenttext: Our next question is from the line of Atif Malik with Morgan Stanley.

headline: Applied Materials Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2010
componenttextpreview: I asked this question last time as well, on the foundry intensity, we've seeing pretty high levels of foundry intensity. Last year, the foundry intensity is the about 45%, so I'm -- just your thoughts on foundry spending, sustainability in the second half
componenttext: I asked this question last time as well, on the foundry intensity, we've seeing pretty high levels of foundry intensity. Last year, the foundry intensity is the about 45%, so I'm -- just your thoughts on foundry spending, sustainability in the second half? I understand the memory can pick up in the second half.

headline: Applied Materials Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2010
componenttextpreview: Yes. I think that right now, the foundry spending has really localized primarily to one company. So what we're expecting to see in the second half is a broader investment from the rest of the members of the foundry community. But I think the leading found
componenttext: Yes. I think that right now, the foundry spending has really localized primarily to one company. So what we're expecting to see in the second half is a broader investment from the rest of the members of the foundry community. But I think the leading foundries have already announced how much they're going to spend for the year. So we're going to see that it's front-half loaded.

headline: Applied Materials Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2010
componenttextpreview: What are the lead times on your Wire Saws, HCT, and Baccini [ph](47:38) business, right now?
componenttext: What are the lead times on your Wire Saws, HCT, and Baccini [ph](47:38) business, right now?

headline: Applied Materials Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2010
componenttextpreview: It's seems like two quarters.
componenttext: It's seems like two quarters.

headline: Applied Materials Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2010
componenttextpreview: Our next question is from the line of Satya Kumar with Crédit Suisse.
componenttext: Our next question is from the line of Satya Kumar with Crédit Suisse.

headline: Applied Materials Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2010
componenttextpreview: Firstly on silicon guidance, if I take the 25% revenue growth you gave in the April quarter and the 100% year-on-year growth, I think you are actually talking about a 50% revenue decline from the April quarter level into July and October. Is that how you'
componenttext: Firstly on silicon guidance, if I take the 25% revenue growth you gave in the April quarter and the 100% year-on-year growth, I think you are actually talking about a 50% revenue decline from the April quarter level into July and October. Is that how you're seeing the year play out in silicone?

headline: Applied Materials Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2010
componenttextpreview: Satya, I think the way we described the second half of the year and the Semiconductor business is -- and you realize there's pretty limited visibility here in the second half at this point. But what we're thinking is it's flat to plus or minus 10% in the
componenttext: Satya, I think the way we described the second half of the year and the Semiconductor business is -- and you realize there's pretty limited visibility here in the second half at this point. But what we're thinking is it's flat to plus or minus 10% in the second half. If we have a strong flash memory investment and we see the rest of the foundry guys coming into the game, we could see plus 10%.If we don't see that, we could kind of get minus 10%. And I think those probably what we're thinking right now.

headline: Applied Materials Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2010
componenttextpreview: In terms of the solar, a quick follow-up, you mentioned that is currently a stabilization in crystalline silicon pricing ahead of the genuine FIT cuts, but still margins are being pressured for your SunFab customers. Supposing we get further pricing press
componenttext: In terms of the solar, a quick follow-up, you mentioned that is currently a stabilization in crystalline silicon pricing ahead of the genuine FIT cuts, but still margins are being pressured for your SunFab customers. Supposing we get further pricing pressure for crystalline silicon after the genuine cuts, would that not cost even more margin pressure on SunFab customers in the quarter? When will the SunFab customers become more competitive with crystalline silicon?

headline: Applied Materials Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2010
componenttextpreview: Well we've been -- certainly, if you look at variable costs, they're already competitive. And they're getting more competitive as we work with them to enhance the performance of the factories, which the factories are really running quite well. So I think
componenttext: Well we've been -- certainly, if you look at variable costs, they're already competitive. And they're getting more competitive as we work with them to enhance the performance of the factories, which the factories are really running quite well. So I think -- but the bigger point on crystalline silicon, if the capacity comes on the way we think it is, there's going to be a lot of pressure on pricing in the second half until more demand is created. We're still looking for demand to be created at a higher level in the U.S., and China and in India, maybe in the second half and into 2011.

headline: Applied Materials Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2010
componenttextpreview: Our next question is from the line of Gary Hsueh with Oppenheimer.
componenttext: Our next question is from the line of Gary Hsueh with Oppenheimer.

headline: Applied Materials Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2010
componenttextpreview: This is Wenge for Gary. You commented on supply chain constraints and combined with your recent hiring of executives for supply chain management. I want to get your opinion on what kind of impact of the supply chain constraint on your costs and operating
componenttext: This is Wenge for Gary. You commented on supply chain constraints and combined with your recent hiring of executives for supply chain management. I want to get your opinion on what kind of impact of the supply chain constraint on your costs and operating expenses in terms of overtimes, higher cost of goods and also the lead time stretch?

headline: Applied Materials Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2010
componenttextpreview: The major impact that we have from the supply chain difficulty this quarter was seen in higher expediting costs and really the cost of logistics in general where above normal. And we're seeing improvements in the supply chain in the second quarter. I thin
componenttext: The major impact that we have from the supply chain difficulty this quarter was seen in higher expediting costs and really the cost of logistics in general where above normal. And we're seeing improvements in the supply chain in the second quarter. I think we'll still have a little bit of work out to do. But there's no connection, really, between our decision to hire an external party in the challenges we're having here. As you know, we're going to be building up our capability in Singapore to strengthen our Pan-Asia supply chain and really, the recent hires in connection with that activity.

headline: Applied Materials Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2010
componenttextpreview: And you guys will get a chance to meet Joe at the Analyst Meeting at the end of March. I think you'll like him. He's got a great background and a great hire for us.
componenttext: And you guys will get a chance to meet Joe at the Analyst Meeting at the end of March. I think you'll like him. He's got a great background and a great hire for us.

headline: Applied Materials Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2010
componenttextpreview: Our next question is from the line of Chris Blansett with JPMorgan.
componenttext: Our next question is from the line of Chris Blansett with JPMorgan.

headline: Applied Materials Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2010
componenttextpreview: Question is related to the share gain you indicated earlier. And I wanted to understand how much the, maybe, mix of demographics of your silicon system customers is playing into this at this time.
componenttext: Question is related to the share gain you indicated earlier. And I wanted to understand how much the, maybe, mix of demographics of your silicon system customers is playing into this at this time.

headline: Applied Materials Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2010
componenttextpreview: Yes. Generally, we try to shake that out of the share gain before we talk about the share gain itself, because if you just look at the last few years, there's been a huge change in overall revenue and buying patterns in the Silicon segments. So when we ta
componenttext: Yes. Generally, we try to shake that out of the share gain before we talk about the share gain itself, because if you just look at the last few years, there's been a huge change in overall revenue and buying patterns in the Silicon segments. So when we talk about share gain, we're really talking about innate gain at customers with winning applications in the various areas, and then that's kind of general. Do you have a specific question, Chris, about one of the product lines?

headline: Applied Materials Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2010
componenttextpreview: Well, I was just trying to dig a little more deeper specifically into the Etch business. There's different types of etch, which some investors aren't aware of. And where you think you're doing better versus where you've been in the past and given the shif
componenttext: Well, I was just trying to dig a little more deeper specifically into the Etch business. There's different types of etch, which some investors aren't aware of. And where you think you're doing better versus where you've been in the past and given the shift that's occurring in the etch market with the Metal Etch product continue to shrink and the dielectric growing. Just maybe some color commentary around that?

headline: Applied Materials Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2010
componenttextpreview: Sure. So we have a significantly more exposure in the memory area. That's, I think, well chronicled. But we've been increasing our applications as well in the memory area both in flash and in DRAM, in particular, strength in the flash areas of double patt
componenttext: Sure. So we have a significantly more exposure in the memory area. That's, I think, well chronicled. But we've been increasing our applications as well in the memory area both in flash and in DRAM, in particular, strength in the flash areas of double patterning that we've done an awful lot of work with customers and have been able to gain applications there, as well as in high aspect contacts and those kind of applications in DRAMs, which are becoming increasingly more prevalent. So those are more dielectric, both are dielectric-oriented. And we're even starting to see some traction now at some of the foundries, which, in the past, logic has really been our weak points in it.

headline: Applied Materials Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2010
componenttextpreview: Our next question is from the line of Steve O'Rourke with Deutsche Bank.
componenttext: Our next question is from the line of Steve O'Rourke with Deutsche Bank.

headline: Applied Materials Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2010
componenttextpreview: First, there's been some reportedly substantial share loss in PVD in one of your significant customers. One, could you comment on your positioning with PVD and how you feel that is? And second question, Turns business in the Silicon business, they're high
componenttext: First, there's been some reportedly substantial share loss in PVD in one of your significant customers. One, could you comment on your positioning with PVD and how you feel that is? And second question, Turns business in the Silicon business, they're high in Q1. Is this kind of the new normal with respect to orders in turns in the quarter?

headline: Applied Materials Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2010
componenttextpreview: Yes. On the PVD, I just say they're following. First of all, I think, primarily what you're aiming at here is copper barrier/seed, which is kind of in the memory area, which is about 30% of the market and 30% of that market, so it's kind of a less than 10
componenttext: Yes. On the PVD, I just say they're following. First of all, I think, primarily what you're aiming at here is copper barrier/seed, which is kind of in the memory area, which is about 30% of the market and 30% of that market, so it's kind of a less than 10%. I don't think there's been any real share shifts. There are shared positions there where we kind of go back and forth. But when you look at the new applications where the market is growing beyond memory, we're quite strong already and the conversion to copper in memory, that's one aspect. But in metal gate silicides, that's a new application, multiple steps in Logic. And then as well as in packaging, where I mentioned that we have a significant buying pattern for our charger PVD system. And we think that we'll end up gaining share and that's based at the end of the year.

headline: Applied Materials Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2010
componenttextpreview: And Steve, on the Turns business and the new normal, what I would say is that we've seen certainly a push from all of our customers to shorten our cycle times and it's one of the reasons why we've gone to a much more modular manufacturing approach and wor
componenttext: And Steve, on the Turns business and the new normal, what I would say is that we've seen certainly a push from all of our customers to shorten our cycle times and it's one of the reasons why we've gone to a much more modular manufacturing approach and work very hard to strengthen our supply chain. I would also say that foundry customers, just by the nature of their end markets and the windows that they have to hit those markets, are probably the shortest cycle customers that we have. And so I think you have a little bit of the foundry effect. So I do think short cycle is certainly new normal. And I would say we're at a -- given the mix of foundry right now, we're at the shorter end of that short cycle. That's probably too many cycles.

headline: Applied Materials Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2010
componenttextpreview: Our next question is from the line of Mehdi Hosseini with Friedman, Billings and Ramsey.
componenttext: Our next question is from the line of Mehdi Hosseini with Friedman, Billings and Ramsey.

headline: Applied Materials Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2010
componenttextpreview: Mike, going back to earlier commentary about the overall size of the -- with your fab equipment market, can you please clarify -- do you say that in order for you to exceed the prior peak of SSG revenue, the market has to be $30 billion or $33 billion? An
componenttext: Mike, going back to earlier commentary about the overall size of the -- with your fab equipment market, can you please clarify -- do you say that in order for you to exceed the prior peak of SSG revenue, the market has to be $30 billion or $33 billion? And are you also assuming that your market share is not going to be a factor in exceeding the prior peak? Or could you please provide some clarification and I have a follow-up.

headline: Applied Materials Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2010
componenttextpreview: Sure, Mehdi. What I said was, it would have to approach $30 billion, which assumes we're going to be able to go faster than WFE [wafer fabrication equipment], because obviously, last peak was quite a bit above that number. So I don't want to go down into
componenttext: Sure, Mehdi. What I said was, it would have to approach $30 billion, which assumes we're going to be able to go faster than WFE [wafer fabrication equipment], because obviously, last peak was quite a bit above that number. So I don't want to go down into all the details. But you can assume that we've made those assumptions. But for right now, our projection for this year is $21 billion to $23 billion for our wafer fab equipment spending.

headline: Applied Materials Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2010
componenttextpreview: And when you expect to the Microprocessor segment of the market to come back? And has there -- there's a lot of talk about share gain and share loss in etch and PVD, can you update us on what's going on with the Microprocessor segment? And when would you
componenttext: And when you expect to the Microprocessor segment of the market to come back? And has there -- there's a lot of talk about share gain and share loss in etch and PVD, can you update us on what's going on with the Microprocessor segment? And when would you expect that segment of the market to come back?

headline: Applied Materials Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2010
componenttextpreview: Well, I think, as you know, microprocessors are on a node of technology that's generally ahead of the rest of the industry. And they invest big in odd years and order in late even years. So that's kind of what I'm expecting to continue. We're very encoura
componenttext: Well, I think, as you know, microprocessors are on a node of technology that's generally ahead of the rest of the industry. And they invest big in odd years and order in late even years. So that's kind of what I'm expecting to continue. We're very encouraged by the growth in the PC market. We thought that we think, overall, the PC market's going to grow 10% to 15% this year. If you saw HP's results earlier today, they said they had 26% increase in PC shipments. That's gigantic. So I would think that if that continues, capacity additions have to follow pretty quickly.

headline: Applied Materials Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2010
componenttextpreview: Our next question is from the line of Patrick Ho with Stifel, Nicolaus.
componenttext: Our next question is from the line of Patrick Ho with Stifel, Nicolaus.

headline: Applied Materials Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2010
componenttextpreview: First, what do you see on maybe on qualitative or even on a quantitative basis, in terms of the customer mix for your semi orders in 2Q? And related to that, can you describe what you could see in terms of the sustainability of DRAM orders, at least over
componenttext: First, what do you see on maybe on qualitative or even on a quantitative basis, in terms of the customer mix for your semi orders in 2Q? And related to that, can you describe what you could see in terms of the sustainability of DRAM orders, at least over the next few quarters? What would drive DRAM orders to be more sustainable than some of the perceptions out there that it'll be a first-half loaded?

headline: Applied Materials Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2010
componenttextpreview: The word I think I would use to describe orders, not only in Q1 but Q2, is concentrated. They are quite concentrated both revenue and orders are still quite concentrated at a very small number of companies. On the sustainability of DRAM, I just think that
componenttext: The word I think I would use to describe orders, not only in Q1 but Q2, is concentrated. They are quite concentrated both revenue and orders are still quite concentrated at a very small number of companies. On the sustainability of DRAM, I just think that depends, in big part, on how the cellphone and PC markets go. Right now, we don't see enough capacity to meet kind of 60% bit growth, if it gets that high. We've been updating our analysis there and our estimates from, I think, earlier in the last call, we said was at 35 to 40. We're kind of now in the 55 to 60. But DRAM is undersupplied right now, and we don't see that getting ahead of demand through the next few quarters.

headline: Applied Materials Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2010
componenttextpreview: Our next question is from the line of Edwin Mok with Needham & Company.
componenttext: Our next question is from the line of Edwin Mok with Needham & Company.

headline: Applied Materials Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2010
componenttextpreview: First question regarding the Silicon side of the business. Mike, you mentioned that you thought to see signs that some customer add new fabs. Any color you can add to that? Is that more for 2011 time frame? And then which area, in terms of memory versus f
componenttext: First question regarding the Silicon side of the business. Mike, you mentioned that you thought to see signs that some customer add new fabs. Any color you can add to that? Is that more for 2011 time frame? And then which area, in terms of memory versus foundry versus DRAM? Are you looking at the -- do you think customer looking to add new fabs?

headline: Applied Materials Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, we're looking at nine new fabs that customers are talking about, we think are coming close to announcements. So maybe they get announced over the next couple of quarters. Almost all these are for 2011 capacity. There's one that could still be up in 2
componenttext: Yes, we're looking at nine new fabs that customers are talking about, we think are coming close to announcements. So maybe they get announced over the next couple of quarters. Almost all these are for 2011 capacity. There's one that could still be up in 2010, late 2010. That one'll be a flash but, but a couple of these are DRAM fabs, several of them are foundry factories. I guess other than naming everyone, I think that's about as far as I'll go.

headline: Applied Materials Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2010
componenttextpreview: Just a whole question regarding the flat-panel display area. You mentioned that you expect capital equipment spending to be up 60% this year, yet you only guide for the revenue to be up 30%? How do I reconcile between that? And I understand you have a new
componenttext: Just a whole question regarding the flat-panel display area. You mentioned that you expect capital equipment spending to be up 60% this year, yet you only guide for the revenue to be up 30%? How do I reconcile between that? And I understand you have a new PVD product in that area too, can you give some color on that?

headline: Applied Materials Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2010
componenttextpreview: Sure, Edwin. The 60% is a calendar-year forecast. And as you know, we have a fiscal year that misses two of those months. We expect the shipment and revenue activity to be strong both in 2010 and the first part of '11. And I think any difference between t
componenttext: Sure, Edwin. The 60% is a calendar-year forecast. And as you know, we have a fiscal year that misses two of those months. We expect the shipment and revenue activity to be strong both in 2010 and the first part of '11. And I think any difference between the market forecast that our revenue forecast is really just revenue timing.

headline: Applied Materials Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2010
componenttextpreview: Our next question is from the line of Gus Richard with Piper Jaffray.
componenttext: Our next question is from the line of Gus Richard with Piper Jaffray.

headline: Applied Materials Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2010
componenttextpreview: Just in terms of the broadening out of spend, a lot of people have difficulty putting in the meters, a lot of won't have cleanroom space, a lot of people don't have money. Sort of, in those constraints, how do you see those getting relieved over the next
componenttext: Just in terms of the broadening out of spend, a lot of people have difficulty putting in the meters, a lot of won't have cleanroom space, a lot of people don't have money. Sort of, in those constraints, how do you see those getting relieved over the next year or so?

headline: Applied Materials Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2010
componenttextpreview: Well, most people have technology partners today. So I think the places where there's real limitations or fundamental limitations on technology are very few. There can always be yield problems and product problems, those kind of things, but I don't think
componenttext: Well, most people have technology partners today. So I think the places where there's real limitations or fundamental limitations on technology are very few. There can always be yield problems and product problems, those kind of things, but I don't think that's fundamental. And I think the money issues that had plagued, the big part of the industry last year when profits were low and in 2008, are slowly being relieved as prices stay high, particularly in memory. And we look at this profitability very, very closely because we do think ability to take on debit customers is a very important factor. It has to get access to capital. And then I do think, of course, there is the question of lift those sale availability. I think that's a thing we also we watch closely because of the cost of that element of the equivalent supply.

headline: Applied Materials Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2010
componenttextpreview: Given the tightness of advanced litho systems in the world today, does that present an opportunity for Applied? And self-aligned double patterning, are you seeing that gain traction with your customers? Or any thoughts there?
componenttext: Given the tightness of advanced litho systems in the world today, does that present an opportunity for Applied? And self-aligned double patterning, are you seeing that gain traction with your customers? Or any thoughts there?

headline: Applied Materials Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, I think we are seeing pretty much everybody trying some level of double patterning, different levels in production, the flash guys clearly have mastered this technique in production these days. And we are working very, very closely. Our share in that
componenttext: Yes, I think we are seeing pretty much everybody trying some level of double patterning, different levels in production, the flash guys clearly have mastered this technique in production these days. And we are working very, very closely. Our share in that space is quite good because of how much knowledge we gained early on in that technology.

headline: Applied Materials Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2010
componenttextpreview: Our next question is from the line of Krish Sankar with Bank of America - Merrill Lynch.
componenttext: Our next question is from the line of Krish Sankar with Bank of America - Merrill Lynch.

headline: Applied Materials Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2010
componenttextpreview: Mike, I just wanted to follow-up on the $21 billion to $23 billion wafer fab spending this year, how high do you think wafer fab equipment spending can go before we hit the roadblock of new fabs or filling out empty shelf? And the follow-up on the cost re
componenttext: Mike, I just wanted to follow-up on the $21 billion to $23 billion wafer fab spending this year, how high do you think wafer fab equipment spending can go before we hit the roadblock of new fabs or filling out empty shelf? And the follow-up on the cost reduction, George, if I it remember right, the $450 million reduction given prior to your Semitool acquisition, supposed Semitool acquisition -- could you update us on what the new goal would be for the cost reduction?

headline: Applied Materials Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2010
componenttextpreview: So we don't see any space issues to $23 billion. I don't think that there are space issues for some significant amount above that. So usually, factory managers and companies are quite imaginative about how to create a space if they need it for capacity. A
componenttext: So we don't see any space issues to $23 billion. I don't think that there are space issues for some significant amount above that. So usually, factory managers and companies are quite imaginative about how to create a space if they need it for capacity. And I don't think we know how to do a calculation that says exactly how much space there is and how much money it would take to fill that space. But it's not a $23 billion.

headline: Applied Materials Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2010
componenttextpreview: And Krish, in terms of cost reduction, the $450 million program is really about long-term structural change for the company. It's not meant to capture all activities in the company. For Semitool, what we've said is that it will be cash-accretive in year o
componenttext: And Krish, in terms of cost reduction, the $450 million program is really about long-term structural change for the company. It's not meant to capture all activities in the company. For Semitool, what we've said is that it will be cash-accretive in year one and a GAAP-accretive in year two and we have synergy programs that support that, but we have not disclosed that.

headline: Applied Materials Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2010
componenttextpreview: Our next question is from the line of Mahesh Sanganeria with RBC Capital Markets.
componenttext: Our next question is from the line of Mahesh Sanganeria with RBC Capital Markets.

headline: Applied Materials Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2010

componenttext: First question on flat panel, you're looking for a strong shipment towards the end of the year but your orders are pretty low, 130. So it's safe to assume that you should have a pretty significant order growth and 100% kind of order growth in FPD [flat panel displays] next quarter?

headline: Applied Materials Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2010

componenttext: We're expecting healthy order growth next quarter.

headline: Applied Materials Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2010
componenttextpreview: Yes. That's George Davis, speaking.
componenttext: Yes. That's George Davis, speaking.

headline: Applied Materials Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2010
componenttextpreview: As you know, we don't guide to orders in individual segments. But Display certainly one of the areas along with the Silicon that we're expecting positive improvement.
componenttext: As you know, we don't guide to orders in individual segments. But Display certainly one of the areas along with the Silicon that we're expecting positive improvement.

headline: Applied Materials Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2010
componenttextpreview: And the second one on your early revenue guidance with silicon system. Of the 100%, is that including the Semitool acquisition, because you said something in your prepared statement, something 100% increase and $2.5 billion, also you said that have increa
componenttext: And the second one on your early revenue guidance with silicon system. Of the 100%, is that including the Semitool acquisition, because you said something in your prepared statement, something 100% increase and $2.5 billion, also you said that have increased...

headline: Applied Materials Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2010
componenttextpreview: No. Those are different things. The 100% does include the effect of Semitools. Remember, we'll have three quarters of Semitool in the year and it includes really all of the factors, whether it be share gain, growth in the market, and we said more than 100
componenttext: No. Those are different things. The 100% does include the effect of Semitools. Remember, we'll have three quarters of Semitool in the year and it includes really all of the factors, whether it be share gain, growth in the market, and we said more than 100%, so that's for the full year. The $2.5 billion is really -- it's just the simple math of saying that we're going to be up more than 50% year-over-year. So that's 50% on top of the $5 billion last year. That's where the $2.5 billion came from.

headline: Applied Materials Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2010
componenttextpreview: Our last question is from the line of Jagadish Iyer with Arete Research.
componenttext: Our last question is from the line of Jagadish Iyer with Arete Research.

headline: Applied Materials Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2010
componenttextpreview: I don't know, Mike, whether you've called out on your silicon market share. I just wanted to point out, what is your market share? What will be your market share by the end of '10 in terms of your served available market for both '10? And what do you thin
componenttext: I don't know, Mike, whether you've called out on your silicon market share. I just wanted to point out, what is your market share? What will be your market share by the end of '10 in terms of your served available market for both '10? And what do you think it will project out for '11, please?

headline: Applied Materials Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2010
componenttextpreview: Sure. We really don't usually give out the specific market share versus our SAM [served available market], Jagadish. I think I can suffice it to say that we think organic gain, two points this year over last year and we pretty much agree with the third pa
componenttext: Sure. We really don't usually give out the specific market share versus our SAM [served available market], Jagadish. I think I can suffice it to say that we think organic gain, two points this year over last year and we pretty much agree with the third party's assessment of our position from last year.

headline: Applied Materials Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2010
componenttextpreview: Mike, given the situation on the SunFab, I was just wondering, that there -- are you going to revisit your strategy in terms of SunFab and Solar? Is that been some changing your customer outlook, given the new entrance and particularly like FITs, which ha
componenttext: Mike, given the situation on the SunFab, I was just wondering, that there -- are you going to revisit your strategy in terms of SunFab and Solar? Is that been some changing your customer outlook, given the new entrance and particularly like FITs, which have higher efficiencies? So I just wanted to find out whether you have any thoughts on that? Any commentary would be great.

headline: Applied Materials Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2010
componenttextpreview: Sure. Obviously, as I said in the prepared remarks, SunFab customers have been challenged in this current environment. The utilization of the SunFab factories is kind of at the same level of the entire industry, some fully loaded, some lowly loaded. But f
componenttext: Sure. Obviously, as I said in the prepared remarks, SunFab customers have been challenged in this current environment. The utilization of the SunFab factories is kind of at the same level of the entire industry, some fully loaded, some lowly loaded. But fundamentally, this technology -- we believe in the technology and if we didn't believe in the technology, we would make some big changes. But right now, what we're focused on is meeting our commitments to customers. I think that's a very important aspect of the what we're doing with SunFab. And these products are really aimed at a market that's really just starting and that's utility scale solar. When you look at the temperature coefficient, when you look at the incident light, when you look at ambient particles in the air versus the efficiency of these panels, installation costs are a huge advantages over other technologies for -- and plus of course, the size of the panels. There's big advantages in this field. Now the field -- the utility scale solar has to develop. It's still very nascent market. It's a very small percentage of the total. As you know, most of the market is rooftop and that's where we've been having a lot of success with our crystalline silicon products as well. So we're still very excited about the overall market. We think it's good for long-term growth and we think we know how to make money in the Equipment business and that's really fundamentally where we are.

componenttext: We'd like to thank everyone for joining us this afternoon. A replay of this call and our earnings presentation will be available on our website today, beginning at 5:00 Pacific Time and until March 3. Thank you for your continued interest in Applied Materials.
