headline: Applied Materials Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-18-2010
componenttextpreview: Great. Good afternoon, guys. Thanks so much for taking the question. Congratulations on the good results.If I get to ask one question on NAND and one question on DRAM, so starting on NAND, it still represents a small - relatively small percentage of the
componenttext:
Great. Good afternoon, guys. Thanks so much for taking the question. Congratulations on the good results.
If I get to ask one question on NAND and one question on DRAM, so starting on NAND, it still represents a small - relatively small percentage of the overall orders and you guys suggested that you thought you saw some acceleration there. I mean, how much - of the new fabs that have been announced, are you starting to see indications for all of those fabs, some of those fabs, and kind of how do you think those layer in over the next couple of quarters? Is a significant portion of the orders in the coming quarter or are they more metered out over the next several quarters?

headline: Applied Materials Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-18-2010
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Jim. And first of all, on NAND, it - we think in 2010 it will end up being roughly 20% of - around - a little bit less than 20% of orders. We see two major fabs that are going to start really giving orders and then delivering revenue in earnest in
componenttext: Thanks, Jim. And first of all, on NAND, it - we think in 2010 it will end up being roughly 20% of - around - a little bit less than 20% of orders. We see two major fabs that are going to start really giving orders and then delivering revenue in earnest in the next couple of quarters. So we think that this is going to start moving quite quickly here in the fourth calendar quarter and into the first calendar quarter of 2011.

headline: Applied Materials Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-18-2010
componenttextpreview: That's helpful. Thank you. And if I could just ask my follow-up on DRAM, you mentioned kind of you expect a moderation in DRAM spending over the remainder of the year. Is that something you previously didn't expect or was that consistent with your previou
componenttext: That's helpful. Thank you. And if I could just ask my follow-up on DRAM, you mentioned kind of you expect a moderation in DRAM spending over the remainder of the year. Is that something you previously didn't expect or was that consistent with your previous expectations?

headline: Applied Materials Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-18-2010
componenttextpreview: That was very consistent with what we thought would happen. A lot of the investment in Taiwan has been technology conversion from trends to stack, and then the bigger DRAM guys have been spending on capacity for a while. So this is pretty much just the cy
componenttext: That was very consistent with what we thought would happen. A lot of the investment in Taiwan has been technology conversion from trends to stack, and then the bigger DRAM guys have been spending on capacity for a while. So this is pretty much just the cycle of how they plan their investments and I think we have been aware of that for some time.

headline: Applied Materials Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-18-2010
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from Stephen Chin with UBS.
componenttext: Your next question comes from Stephen Chin with UBS.

headline: Applied Materials Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-18-2010
componenttextpreview: Hi, great. Thanks. Hi Mike and George. Just a question on the silicon backlog, which looked like it grew another 13% sequentially this quarter. Could you share with us any color on what that increase was reflective of? It is - is that also reflective of m
componenttext: Hi, great. Thanks. Hi Mike and George. Just a question on the silicon backlog, which looked like it grew another 13% sequentially this quarter. Could you share with us any color on what that increase was reflective of? It is - is that also reflective of maybe larger NAND fabs showing up in backlog?

headline: Applied Materials Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-18-2010
componenttextpreview: No, still - DRAM and foundry were still the stronger - strongest contributors to our order book this quarter. So as Mike said, we really expect NAND to start to pick up in the fourth quarter and beyond as - and DRAM to maybe back off from being quite so s
componenttext: No, still - DRAM and foundry were still the stronger - strongest contributors to our order book this quarter. So as Mike said, we really expect NAND to start to pick up in the fourth quarter and beyond as - and DRAM to maybe back off from being quite so significant a component.

headline: Applied Materials Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-18-2010
componenttextpreview: And Stephen, did you have any follow-up?
componenttext: And Stephen, did you have any follow-up?

headline: Applied Materials Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-18-2010
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from Chris Blansett with JP Morgan.
componenttext: Your next question comes from Chris Blansett with JP Morgan.

headline: Applied Materials Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-18-2010
componenttextpreview: Chris, can you hear us?
componenttext: Chris, can you hear us?

headline: Applied Materials Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-18-2010
componenttextpreview: Can you guys hear me now? I apologize.
componenttext: Can you guys hear me now? I apologize.

headline: Applied Materials Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-18-2010
componenttextpreview: Okay. No problem. We thought you lost - we lost you there for a second, Chris.
componenttext: Okay. No problem. We thought you lost - we lost you there for a second, Chris.

headline: Applied Materials Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-18-2010
componenttextpreview: I did too. I wanted to ask about the manufacturing transition that's going on out in Asia and how we should expect this to progress over, say, the next 12 months, obviously trying to get a feel for how you think gross margins and tax rates are going to tr
componenttext: I did too. I wanted to ask about the manufacturing transition that's going on out in Asia and how we should expect this to progress over, say, the next 12 months, obviously trying to get a feel for how you think gross margins and tax rates are going to trend over that time period.

headline: Applied Materials Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-18-2010
componenttextpreview: Sure. We have got two major initiatives. One is the large area manufacturing, which is moving from Europe and the U.S. to Taiwan. That has been underway for some time and as I said, we are now shipping over 90% of our large area tools out of Taiwan. We ex
componenttext:
Sure. We have got two major initiatives. One is the large area manufacturing, which is moving from Europe and the U.S. to Taiwan. That has been underway for some time and as I said, we are now shipping over 90% of our large area tools out of Taiwan. We expect over time 3 to 4 gross margin points' benefit for display from that move. They are not getting all of that right now because they have got - a lot of their supply chain is still Europe-based, and they are in the process of converting that.
In Singapore, we are in the early days of our ramp of the Singapore facility, which will be combined with Austin to handle all of the shipments for our semiconductor equipment business. We expect that to continue over time. We set out by 2012 we would expect 50% of our shipments to be coming out of Singapore.
But combined with the activities in those facilities, we also have a major supply chain initiative. Given the location of our customers in Asia, we really are putting a lot of effort into a Pan-Asia supply chain expansion, and that's where you will start to see the impact on the tax rate as more activity flows through our Singapore hub. And we will talk about that in the fourth quarter call when we give the outlook for next year, but we would expect to see a noticeable improvement in our tax rate in 2011.

headline: Applied Materials Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-18-2010
componenttextpreview: All right. And then I guess there was some - a little bit of news flow that you may need to hire a little bit in Austin, Texas to kind of meet the near-term demand trends, and this doesn't really change the timeline for moving manufacturing to Asia?
componenttext: All right. And then I guess there was some - a little bit of news flow that you may need to hire a little bit in Austin, Texas to kind of meet the near-term demand trends, and this doesn't really change the timeline for moving manufacturing to Asia?

headline: Applied Materials Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-18-2010
componenttextpreview: No, we - Austin is going to be important part of our manufacturing activities for many years, and so we have had a pattern for several years of temporary fluctuation in workforce as the peaks and valleys of the cycle take place. So, I would say, we certai
componenttext: No, we - Austin is going to be important part of our manufacturing activities for many years, and so we have had a pattern for several years of temporary fluctuation in workforce as the peaks and valleys of the cycle take place. So, I would say, we certainly - this has been an extremely strong ramp for sure. But we are used to hiring and working with a very talented temporary workforce in Austin.

headline: Applied Materials Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-18-2010
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from C.J. Muse with Barclays Capital.
componenttext: Your next question comes from C.J. Muse with Barclays Capital.

headline: Applied Materials Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-18-2010
componenttextpreview: Good afternoon. Thanks for taking my questions. I guess, first question, in prepared remarks you expressed an outlook for strong bookings (inaudible). I was hoping you could explain that per se [ph] in total and then individually within these segments how
componenttext: Good afternoon. Thanks for taking my questions. I guess, first question, in prepared remarks you expressed an outlook for strong bookings (inaudible). I was hoping you could explain that per se [ph] in total and then individually within these segments how we should think about moving parts there? (Multiple Speakers)

headline: Applied Materials Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-18-2010
componenttextpreview: Yes. C.J., I think you are asking about bookings. You were cutting out. Let me just - we haven't guided on bookings. We - quite frankly, we see a pretty strong bookings outlook across our businesses. Again, in semi-cap equipment, we don't expect a falloff
componenttext:
Yes. C.J., I think you are asking about bookings. You were cutting out. Let me just - we haven't guided on bookings. We - quite frankly, we see a pretty strong bookings outlook across our businesses. Again, in semi-cap equipment, we don't expect a falloff at all there. And as I said, we expect - right now, Q1 is looking stronger than from a shipment standpoint than Q4, which bodes well for orders.
In crystalline, obviously, we had an extremely strong quarter already in the third quarter. But again, we are continuing to see strong orders. If they come off a little bit, it's coming off of kind of records for those - for our two businesses there. In AGS, refurbished equipment is providing a nice boost in the order outlook there. We expect that to continue into the fourth quarter. So across the board, we are seeing a very strong continuing order interest across our businesses.

headline: Applied Materials Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-18-2010
componenttextpreview: Very helpful. And if I could ask a follow-up, if you can hear me. In the last month or so, we have seen weakness in the LCD (inaudible) panel pricing coming down and utilizations getting cut, particularly in Japan and Taiwan. I am wondering if that's impa
componenttext: Very helpful. And if I could ask a follow-up, if you can hear me. In the last month or so, we have seen weakness in the LCD (inaudible) panel pricing coming down and utilizations getting cut, particularly in Japan and Taiwan. I am wondering if that's impacting your service business at all or whether you have seen any softening in your outlook for orders, one, two, three quarters out from China and Taiwan.

headline: Applied Materials Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-18-2010
componenttextpreview: Right. In the LCD business, they have been really quite cognizant of the inventory growth and really are taking actions to get that inventory absorbed. Most of the inventory is not an LED kind of backlit panel, so it's important for them to move that inve
componenttext: Right. In the LCD business, they have been really quite cognizant of the inventory growth and really are taking actions to get that inventory absorbed. Most of the inventory is not an LED kind of backlit panel, so it's important for them to move that inventory quickly and take actions, but we really haven't seen a meaningful fall-off in service there or any realigning or rescheduling of deliveries or factory startups. In particular, there are some factories going into China now which are - look like they are going to just stay on schedule if not pull in a bit.

headline: Applied Materials Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-18-2010
componenttextpreview: Thanks, C.J.
componenttext: Thanks, C.J.

headline: Applied Materials Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-18-2010
componenttextpreview: I might just add on that point that we are hearing some increased discussion now about Gen 10 and Gen 11, which I think - and the overall long-term confidence in that market is positive.
componenttext: I might just add on that point that we are hearing some increased discussion now about Gen 10 and Gen 11, which I think - and the overall long-term confidence in that market is positive.

headline: Applied Materials Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-18-2010
componenttextpreview: Great.
componenttext: Great.

headline: Applied Materials Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-18-2010
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from Krish Sankar with Bank of America.
componenttext: Your next question comes from Krish Sankar with Bank of America.

headline: Applied Materials Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-18-2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, thanks for taking my question. Mike, I kind of had a bid picture question. If you assume the macro deteriorates from here onwards, which customer segment of yours would be the first to scale back buying equipment? Do you think it's going to be foundr
componenttext: Yes, thanks for taking my question. Mike, I kind of had a bid picture question. If you assume the macro deteriorates from here onwards, which customer segment of yours would be the first to scale back buying equipment? Do you think it's going to be foundry, DRAM, NAND or logic? And I had a follow-up too.

headline: Applied Materials Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-18-2010
componenttextpreview: That's a pretty good question, Krish. It's hard to know exactly, but you know, you take a look at what's going on right now in kind of the product area and there is a lot of exciting products that are selling into the Asian economies, emerging economies a
componenttext:
That's a pretty good question, Krish. It's hard to know exactly, but you know, you take a look at what's going on right now in kind of the product area and there is a lot of exciting products that are selling into the Asian economies, emerging economies around the world, the smartphones, the Droid phones, iPad, new computers, and LED TVs.
So if there really is a consumer pullback, it will be some of those companies that are really committed to those consumer products. And I think you probably see it in memory first, because they are just so tied to all those different products; and then in the non-microprocessor MPU companies, so then you start to see it - see the commitment to - have issue in foundries. But so far utilization is still quite high there and no investment pullbacks yet.

headline: Applied Materials Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-18-2010
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Mike. That's very helpful. And then you kind of mentioned that the DRAM CapEx is going to slow down through the rest of the year. Do you have any view or early read on what DRAM CapEx would be in calendar 2011? Thanks a lot.
componenttext: Thanks, Mike. That's very helpful. And then you kind of mentioned that the DRAM CapEx is going to slow down through the rest of the year. Do you have any view or early read on what DRAM CapEx would be in calendar 2011? Thanks a lot.

headline: Applied Materials Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-18-2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, we are really not ready to project 2011 yet. And as an overall number for WFE or for CapEx other than the things that the percentages are going to stay relatively the same, if not move up a little bit. WFE this year is still at 9% of semiconductor re
componenttext: Yes, we are really not ready to project 2011 yet. And as an overall number for WFE or for CapEx other than the things that the percentages are going to stay relatively the same, if not move up a little bit. WFE this year is still at 9% of semiconductor revenue and CapEx is at 14 - a little over 14% versus semiconductor revenues. So these are still relatively low levels compared to historic, so we don't think there is over-capacity at this point and still think, if the macroeconomics hold in there, 2011 will be a very strong year.

headline: Applied Materials Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-18-2010
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from Peter Kim with Deutsche Bank.
componenttext: Your next question comes from Peter Kim with Deutsche Bank.

headline: Applied Materials Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-18-2010
componenttextpreview: Yes. Thanks for taking my question. The first question is with regards to the balance, the $300 million in backlog for thin films. I was wondering how long do you think it will be before you can flush it out through the system, and when they do flow throu
componenttext: Yes. Thanks for taking my question. The first question is with regards to the balance, the $300 million in backlog for thin films. I was wondering how long do you think it will be before you can flush it out through the system, and when they do flow through your income statement, what kind of operating margins will they run at?

headline: Applied Materials Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-18-2010
componenttextpreview: Sure. The - we expect over the next two quarters to sign off those factories. One of the factories should have positive operating margins. The other one will - is basically a zero-margin deal. So the largest has a positive operating margin.
componenttext: Sure. The - we expect over the next two quarters to sign off those factories. One of the factories should have positive operating margins. The other one will - is basically a zero-margin deal. So the largest has a positive operating margin.

headline: Applied Materials Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-18-2010
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then for the follow-up, with regards to your customer concentration, I was wondering, specifically with - on the foundries, has your - have you grown foundries orders on a broader base of customers or do you - is it still being carried pretty mu
componenttext: Okay. And then for the follow-up, with regards to your customer concentration, I was wondering, specifically with - on the foundries, has your - have you grown foundries orders on a broader base of customers or do you - is it still being carried pretty much by a narrow focus of customers?

headline: Applied Materials Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-18-2010
componenttextpreview: The number of customers has actually increased. The - all foundries now are adding capacity. Certainly the top five or six foundries are all adding capacity at this point and actually picking up for the number one foundry who has spent a lot of their capa
componenttext: The number of customers has actually increased. The - all foundries now are adding capacity. Certainly the top five or six foundries are all adding capacity at this point and actually picking up for the number one foundry who has spent a lot of their capacity early on.

headline: Applied Materials Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-18-2010
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from Gary Hsueh with Oppenheimer.
componenttext: Your next question comes from Gary Hsueh with Oppenheimer.

headline: Applied Materials Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-18-2010
componenttextpreview: Hi, thanks for taking my question, and congrats on a solid quarter. A Quick question here on - I've been following the NAND flash manufacturers and they have been clearly much more bullish here in terms of getting into 2011, thinking about a 100% plus bit
componenttext:
Hi, thanks for taking my question, and congrats on a solid quarter. A Quick question here on - I've been following the NAND flash manufacturers and they have been clearly much more bullish here in terms of getting into 2011, thinking about a 100% plus bit growth again in 2011 and most manufacturers are talking about much better than seasonal forecast for NAND flash this early out already in Q1.
So have you started to see any reacceleration or pull-ins of NAND flash equipment and particularly for new fabs? And just thinking about an offset, I'm just wondering in terms of the offset relative to maybe a digesting period in terms of solar equipment orders from foundries, how much of an offset are do you think the NAND flash manufacturers could be?

headline: Applied Materials Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-18-2010
componenttextpreview: Well, we would agree with you on outlook on a 100% bit growth - growing bit growth certainly over the 70% to 80% that we saw in 2010. A lot of it depends on how strong tablet PC - or tablet category is in 2011, but if it meets even the midpoint of project
componenttext: Well, we would agree with you on outlook on a 100% bit growth - growing bit growth certainly over the 70% to 80% that we saw in 2010. A lot of it depends on how strong tablet PC - or tablet category is in 2011, but if it meets even the midpoint of projection, it's going to drive a lot of flash memory. As I said, we see the two big fabs that are coming on in flash memory, we think that those will move very quickly and if they can pull in startups, will pull in startups.

headline: Applied Materials Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-18-2010
componenttextpreview: Okay. And just a follow-up question here. I don't think you guys have gotten enough credit on market share execution. Could you just say how well your market share execution has gone, particularly in the NAND flash segment, and how that sets you up in ter
componenttext: Okay. And just a follow-up question here. I don't think you guys have gotten enough credit on market share execution. Could you just say how well your market share execution has gone, particularly in the NAND flash segment, and how that sets you up in terms of driving orders and revenue a few quarters out? Thank you.

headline: Applied Materials Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-18-2010
componenttextpreview: Sure. Thanks, Gary. Well, first of all, maybe we can just kind of take an overall view and kind of the way we look at our calculation. We think that WFE is in the $26 billion to $28 billion and we look at what our revenue will be in calendar 2010. We are
componenttext:
Sure. Thanks, Gary. Well, first of all, maybe we can just kind of take an overall view and kind of the way we look at our calculation. We think that WFE is in the $26 billion to $28 billion and we look at what our revenue will be in calendar 2010. We are quite sure that we will gain at least 2 points of share just doing that math.
We are quite - of course bigger foundry spending is good for Applied Materials because of our exposure in Epi, annealing, and transistor and metallization levels, but really where we like - where we are gaining in our lower share products like inspection and in Etch is particularly both in DRAM and in Flash. But we see significant gains at major flash manufacturers, particularly in Etch, and we are quite excited about those going forward.

headline: Applied Materials Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-18-2010
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from Atif Malik with Morgan Stanley.
componenttext: Your next question comes from Atif Malik with Morgan Stanley.

headline: Applied Materials Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-18-2010
componenttextpreview: Hi, thanks for taking my question. This is Mike Chu for Atif. Just a question on - given the macro, have you started to see any push-outs during the quarter and if so, what segments might have those come from?
componenttext: Hi, thanks for taking my question. This is Mike Chu for Atif. Just a question on - given the macro, have you started to see any push-outs during the quarter and if so, what segments might have those come from?

headline: Applied Materials Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-18-2010
componenttextpreview: No real push-outs, Mike, during the quarter. As we said, we are very mindful of the macroeconomic news and really watching that carefully. But we are trying to spend as much time with customers to understand what they are thinking about in their supply ch
componenttext: No real push-outs, Mike, during the quarter. As we said, we are very mindful of the macroeconomic news and really watching that carefully. But we are trying to spend as much time with customers to understand what they are thinking about in their supply chain and their investment plans for the upcoming quarters. But right now, nobody is backing off.

headline: Applied Materials Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-18-2010
componenttextpreview: And as a follow-up, could you just provide an update if you can on the LED side?
componenttext: And as a follow-up, could you just provide an update if you can on the LED side?

headline: Applied Materials Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-18-2010
componenttextpreview: Well, we are still working on a product. We are quite happy with the technical progress that we are making with the customers that we are working on, but we haven't introduced this product yet. We will, but I think we will save all the details for that ti
componenttext: Well, we are still working on a product. We are quite happy with the technical progress that we are making with the customers that we are working on, but we haven't introduced this product yet. We will, but I think we will save all the details for that time.

headline: Applied Materials Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-18-2010
componenttextpreview: All right. Thank you.
componenttext: All right. Thank you.

headline: Applied Materials Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-18-2010
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from Satya Kumar with Credit Suisse.
componenttext: Your next question comes from Satya Kumar with Credit Suisse.

headline: Applied Materials Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-18-2010
componenttextpreview: Hi, this is Viji Subramanyam [ph] calling in place of Satya. Congratulations on a very good quarter. So Mike, you are not ready to give your view on 2011. Maybe you can give your early view on 2012 maybe?
componenttext: Hi, this is Viji Subramanyam [ph] calling in place of Satya. Congratulations on a very good quarter. So Mike, you are not ready to give your view on 2011. Maybe you can give your early view on 2012 maybe?

headline: Applied Materials Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-18-2010
componenttextpreview: I am really not ready to talk about 2012, but I do like the positioning - early positioning. When I look at 28 nanometers, which will be pretty much a dominant technology in logic ramping in 2012, I really like the positional share wins that we have there
componenttext:
I am really not ready to talk about 2012, but I do like the positioning - early positioning. When I look at 28 nanometers, which will be pretty much a dominant technology in logic ramping in 2012, I really like the positional share wins that we have there, not only in Etch and in inspection, but also in those products that are exposed to transistors. Transistors are just going to get a lot more complicated. So we are excited about that.
In silicon, we think solar crystalline silicon, solar in particular, is going to continue to expand at a rapid pace as prices come down and display is going to continue to be in best at 8% or 9% of overall revenue. So we like our expanding position there. Our PVD system is very, very beneficial for customers in their cost of ownership, so we think we have expanding position there as well.

headline: Applied Materials Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-18-2010
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Mike. I have one more follow-up question. During SEMICON, you had mentioned that you are working with more than 15 TSV customers and you are qualified in three different customers. Can you provide us any update on the TSV customer status, as we
componenttext: Thank you, Mike. I have one more follow-up question. During SEMICON, you had mentioned that you are working with more than 15 TSV customers and you are qualified in three different customers. Can you provide us any update on the TSV customer status, as well as the total opportunity from that space in 2011? And you had mentioned that the Semitool revenue is accretive, so I wanted to find out if it is both in plating, as well as clean?

headline: Applied Materials Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-18-2010
componenttextpreview: Sure. I will let George handle the Semitool. And I will just comment a bit on wafer-level packing and TSV in particular. This is still an emerging area, but it's one of those areas where we think we have the - by far the strongest offering in the industry
componenttext:
Sure. I will let George handle the Semitool. And I will just comment a bit on wafer-level packing and TSV in particular. This is still an emerging area, but it's one of those areas where we think we have the - by far the strongest offering in the industry. We are working with quite a number of customers. We have had some big wins during this - very exciting wins during this quarter in TSV.
In 2011, it's still not going to be a very big market. I will talk more about that when we get to 2011, but this is going to be the way people package semiconductors over the long haul. So, this market is going to grow very, very fast over the next few years.

headline: Applied Materials Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-18-2010
componenttextpreview: And then on Semitool, it's - the accretive is based on their total business, which includes both plating and cleans.
componenttext: And then on Semitool, it's - the accretive is based on their total business, which includes both plating and cleans.

headline: Applied Materials Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-18-2010
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from Tim Arcuri with Citi.
componenttext: Your next question comes from Tim Arcuri with Citi.

headline: Applied Materials Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-18-2010
componenttextpreview: This is Wenge Yang for Tim. A couple of questions. First, regarding the crystalline solar there. We have seen capacity ramps for several quarters, and while the module makers are very excited about the current demand, they are also very nervous. Could you
componenttext: This is Wenge Yang for Tim. A couple of questions. First, regarding the crystalline solar there. We have seen capacity ramps for several quarters, and while the module makers are very excited about the current demand, they are also very nervous. Could you provide some color on what's the outlook for continuous ramp? Is there any sign that that could have - take a pause in the near-term? And I have a quick follow-up.

headline: Applied Materials Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-18-2010
componenttextpreview: I would just say that the major solar cell manufacturers are - their factories are fully loaded. They are not meeting demand today. I can't say that about all the rest of the customers. But if you take the top 10 or 15, they are all full and ramping as -
componenttext:
I would just say that the major solar cell manufacturers are - their factories are fully loaded. They are not meeting demand today. I can't say that about all the rest of the customers. But if you take the top 10 or 15, they are all full and ramping as - pretty much as fast as they can. There is, as you know, a lot of contract arrangements being made now that help the top-tier guys with their capacity.
So, we just see very, very strong orders yet and full factories and no step-back from that at the current time. In fact, a lot of the discussions now about even 2011 are strong, but as I said, there is 11 to 13 gigawatts capacity being put in, that's a heck of a lot of capacity. But we haven't seen signs of pullback at this point.

headline: Applied Materials Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-18-2010
componenttextpreview: Okay. Just a quick follow-up for George. With the organization change, a lot of things moving, could you provide some new guidance on your OpEx in the coming quarters? Thank you.
componenttext: Okay. Just a quick follow-up for George. With the organization change, a lot of things moving, could you provide some new guidance on your OpEx in the coming quarters? Thank you.

headline: Applied Materials Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-18-2010
componenttextpreview: Yes. So we have been operating at about $520 million to $540 million in OpEx over the past few quarters. Really, the outlook next year will determine whether it's up or down and we have got - we made good progress on our cost reduction programs throughout
componenttext: Yes. So we have been operating at about $520 million to $540 million in OpEx over the past few quarters. Really, the outlook next year will determine whether it's up or down and we have got - we made good progress on our cost reduction programs throughout the company. We are about halfway through the $200 million and $250 million in OpEx reductions. We will continue to see that reflected in the numbers. And then we will just determine whether or not the business is up or flat to determine where overall OpEx comes out. But we are very pleased with the progress we have made on our cost structure.

headline: Applied Materials Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-18-2010
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from Patrick Ho with Stifel Nicolaus.

headline: Applied Materials Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-18-2010
componenttextpreview: Thanks a lot. First off, I think last quarter you mentioned that you saw a relatively high level of turns business and you thought that could be the norm going forward. Can you just comment on what you saw this quarter and whether you expect that to conti
componenttext: Thanks a lot. First off, I think last quarter you mentioned that you saw a relatively high level of turns business and you thought that could be the norm going forward. Can you just comment on what you saw this quarter and whether you expect that to continue like you said last quarter?

headline: Applied Materials Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-18-2010
componenttextpreview: We do. We think it will continue and in particular, foundry customers tend to be some of the shortest-cycled customers in terms of order profile. So it's gotten a little bit better, but it's - we still will expect to see a lot of dialog early in the quart
componenttext: We do. We think it will continue and in particular, foundry customers tend to be some of the shortest-cycled customers in terms of order profile. So it's gotten a little bit better, but it's - we still will expect to see a lot of dialog early in the quarter.

headline: Applied Materials Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-18-2010
componenttextpreview: Great. And my follow-up, in terms of the growth at - in your Baccini business, can you characterize whether the strength is coming primarily from share gains in new customers or is this strength coming from, I guess, the capacity buys returning from your
componenttext: Great. And my follow-up, in terms of the growth at - in your Baccini business, can you characterize whether the strength is coming primarily from share gains in new customers or is this strength coming from, I guess, the capacity buys returning from your existing customer base?

headline: Applied Materials Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-18-2010
componenttextpreview: We think that - the answer is both, Patrick. We think that during this year we will gain something approaching 10 points in Cell Systems at Baccini, but there is huge expansion in China where we are both gaining share and we see such a large level of expa
componenttext:
We think that - the answer is both, Patrick. We think that during this year we will gain something approaching 10 points in Cell Systems at Baccini, but there is huge expansion in China where we are both gaining share and we see such a large level of expansion.
Remember, my comment early on was that there is 80% growth year-over-year in the crystalline silicon spending, so some of that is share gain, some of that is the incumbent customers spending a lot more. Today, we have something over 80 customers in China. So there are a lot of new customers this year that represent that gain in share.

componenttext: No, I think we gave some characterization of the guidance. We think it will be another strong quarter for SSG and display will be picking up, AGS will be picking up. So we should see a strong flow-through in the quarter, so I can't reconcile your gross margin estimate, but we think we will see a good flow-through this quarter.

headline: Applied Materials Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-18-2010
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then just a follow-up question on the silicon side. If I look at your logic order, it was pretty - it was actually a sizable increase sequentially in the fiscal third quarter, and I guess your comment suggests that it will be stronger in the com
componenttext: Okay. And then just a follow-up question on the silicon side. If I look at your logic order, it was pretty - it was actually a sizable increase sequentially in the fiscal third quarter, and I guess your comment suggests that it will be stronger in the coming quarter as well. I was wondering how concentrated are those orders and I saw a lot of logic customers moving more towards foundry model. How do we reconcile that?

headline: Applied Materials Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-18-2010
componenttextpreview: Well, we do think that logic orders will be up substantially. They were up substantially Q3 over Q2, and will be up substantially in Q4 over Q3. The number of standalone logic companies are down, but there is an increased number of them that are ordering
componenttext: Well, we do think that logic orders will be up substantially. They were up substantially Q3 over Q2, and will be up substantially in Q4 over Q3. The number of standalone logic companies are down, but there is an increased number of them that are ordering in Q4. But you can imagine still there is - the largest of those logic customers is the main part of that increase.

headline: Applied Materials Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-18-2010
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from Mahesh Sanganeria with RBC Capital Markets.
componenttext: Your next question comes from Mahesh Sanganeria with RBC Capital Markets.

headline: Applied Materials Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-18-2010
componenttextpreview: Thank you. Thank you for taking the question. A question on the 200 millimeter tool, if you can provide some color on how to model that, you had $100 million - sort of AGS orders grew $100 million, that is non-typical, and your revenue is also growing in
componenttext:
Thank you. Thank you for taking the question. A question on the 200 millimeter tool, if you can provide some color on how to model that, you had $100 million - sort of AGS orders grew $100 million, that is non-typical, and your revenue is also growing in line with that. So the key questions I have is where are you seeing the strength from? Is it analog fabs or China foundry or the logic - or logic fabs and how sustainable that is?
And another question, you said something about margin - operating margin getting hit because of 200 millimeter ramp, if you can clarify that, because I would think that these 200 millimeter tools will be very high margin; it will be probably more than your Silicon System Group margin, because it's probably 1Gs and 2Gs. So that will be helpful. Thanks.

headline: Applied Materials Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-18-2010
componenttextpreview: Well, why don't I cover the financial end of this? The financial impact was really a lot of work around getting tools out that were still required some additional parts from the supply chain. The supply chain for 200 millimeter was much colder than the 30
componenttext:
Well, why don't I cover the financial end of this? The financial impact was really a lot of work around getting tools out that were still required some additional parts from the supply chain. The supply chain for 200 millimeter was much colder than the 300 millimeter supply chain and was not prepared for a very strong and immediate increase in demand for tools. So firing that back up led to what I would describe as under absorption of our manufacturing in the quarter and that impacted margin.
200 millimeter is a good business for us. I won't comment on the specifics of the margins, but it will be positive to AGS' margins for the quarter. And if you look at the order book, the lion's share of the - what I would call the kind of non-linear growth that you would expect out of wafer fab - or excuse me, out of wafer starts is 100% explained by the orders for 200 millimeter equipment.
And maybe Mike, you want to talk a little bit about the location of - who is demanding 200 millimeter equipment?

headline: Applied Materials Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-18-2010
componenttextpreview: Sure. What we are seeing from the demand aspect is it's pretty broad-based in this segment from analog, automotive, foundry, and MEMS growing capacity, the sustainability of which is pretty good. I think - especially when you look at the analog and automo
componenttext: Sure. What we are seeing from the demand aspect is it's pretty broad-based in this segment from analog, automotive, foundry, and MEMS growing capacity, the sustainability of which is pretty good. I think - especially when you look at the analog and automotive parts, those parts aren't going to go off 200 millimeter; MEMS is just getting onto 200 millimeter. So we think that this market is going to see some - certainly some significant growth in the next couple of quarters and then stabilize at a high and sustainable level.

headline: Applied Materials Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-18-2010
componenttextpreview: Just a quick follow-up. If you can - I mean, the business has been improving overall for a while and I am just wondering what was the cause for this step-up. And if you can give us some indication of what is a normalized run rate for 200 millimeter, and a
componenttext: Just a quick follow-up. If you can - I mean, the business has been improving overall for a while and I am just wondering what was the cause for this step-up. And if you can give us some indication of what is a normalized run rate for 200 millimeter, and are we looking at the new run rate going forward?

headline: Applied Materials Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-18-2010
componenttextpreview: I don't think we really have a normalized run rate coming after '08, really the demand dropped off so significantly. It's not clear whether we are seeing the start of a new normalized run rate or just catch-up for under investment in '09 and some requirem
componenttext: I don't think we really have a normalized run rate coming after '08, really the demand dropped off so significantly. It's not clear whether we are seeing the start of a new normalized run rate or just catch-up for under investment in '09 and some requirements for 2010. We are certainly seeing, as Mike said, some new customers and new customer groups looking at it, but we don't have a normalized run rate for you. Thank you.

headline: Applied Materials Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-18-2010
componenttextpreview: Thank you.
componenttext: Thank you.

componenttextpreview: No good deed goes unpunished. The - really, we wanted to give an indication because we were - the order pattern would - if you saw kind of a flattening out quarter-over-quarter, it might not be clear that we are starting to see indications of upward shipm
componenttext:
No good deed goes unpunished. The - really, we wanted to give an indication because we were - the order pattern would - if you saw kind of a flattening out quarter-over-quarter, it might not be clear that we are starting to see indications of upward shipments in Q1. So we just wanted to give a little bit more visibility into that, because we had it.
Display, as we have said, we expect spending to continue to be strong; it can be lumpy though. And so orders and revenue get to be a little lumpy. So we don't - going out two quarters I am trying to give a forecast there. We will give you a better indication on that coming and then AGS will be a function of the continuing demand for 200 millimeter.

headline: Applied Materials Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-18-2010
componenttextpreview: Okay. And the follow-up question is, what are your lead times in your crystalline silicon equipment, are they stretching, are they coming down? And is there any - can you quantify in terms of share gains how much would you be able to gain in '11 in your c
componenttext: Okay. And the follow-up question is, what are your lead times in your crystalline silicon equipment, are they stretching, are they coming down? And is there any - can you quantify in terms of share gains how much would you be able to gain in '11 in your crystalline silicon segment? Thank you.

headline: Applied Materials Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-18-2010
componenttextpreview: Overall, lead times have stabilized. Our manufacturing capability has really dramatically improved over the last few quarters. The - just the testimony to the revenue in this last quarter from both our PWS and from Baccini Cell Systems is - kind of gives
componenttext: Overall, lead times have stabilized. Our manufacturing capability has really dramatically improved over the last few quarters. The - just the testimony to the revenue in this last quarter from both our PWS and from Baccini Cell Systems is - kind of gives you an indicator that we are delivering and delivering to the needs of those customers. I'm not going to project any share gain. We had a big goal for 2010. The teams met that goal, so we will them a new goal in 2011, and talk to you about that maybe at the next call.

headline: Applied Materials Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-18-2010
componenttextpreview: Good day, and welcome to Applied Materials Third Quarter of Fiscal 2010 Earnings Call. Please note that today's call will contain forward-looking statements, which are all statements other than those of historical fact, including statements regarding indu
componenttext:
Good day, and welcome to Applied Materials Third Quarter of Fiscal 2010 Earnings Call. Please note that today's call will contain forward-looking statements, which are all statements other than those of historical fact, including statements regarding industry outlook, customer spending and Applied's opportunities, strategic position, operational initiatives, restructuring activities and Q4 and fiscal 2010 forecast. All forward-looking statements are subject to known and unknown risk and uncertainties that could cause actual results to differ materially from those expressed or implied by such statement. Information concerning these risk factors is contained in today's earnings press release and in the company's filing with the SEC, including its most recent Form 10-Q. Forward-looking statements are based on information as of August 18, 2010, and Applied assumes no obligation to update such statements.
Today's call also contains non-GAAP financial measures, both historical and forecasted. Reconciliations of the GAAP and non-GAAP measures are contained in today's earnings release or in the financial highlights slides, which are available on the Investor page of Applied's website at amat.com. 
I would now like to turn the conference over to Michael Sullivan, Vice President of Investor Relations. Please go ahead, sir.

headline: Applied Materials Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-18-2010
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Carrie, and good afternoon. Joining me today are Mike Splinter, our Chairman and CEO; George Davis, our Chief Financial Officer; and Joe Sweeney, our General Counsel and Corporate Secretary. Today, we'll discuss results for our third fiscal qua
componenttext:
Thank you, Carrie, and good afternoon. Joining me today are Mike Splinter, our Chairman and CEO; George Davis, our Chief Financial Officer; and Joe Sweeney, our General Counsel and Corporate Secretary. Today, we'll discuss results for our third fiscal quarter, which ended August 1. Our earnings release was issued at 1:05 Pacific Time, and you can find a copy on Business Wire or on our website at amat.com. 
Mike Splinter will be off the call with comments on the industry environment, along with our performance and plans. George will follow with comments on our financial performance for the third quarter and our expectations for Q4. We'll then open the call for your questions.
And with that, I'd like to hand the call over to Mike Splinter.

headline: Applied Materials Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-18-2010
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Mike. Applied delivered solid third quarter results driven by our Semiconductor, Display and Crystalline Silicon Solar businesses. Sales were up 10% and earnings per share were $0.03 above the range of our forecast. During the quarter, we announce
componenttext:
Thanks, Mike. Applied delivered solid third quarter results driven by our Semiconductor, Display and Crystalline Silicon Solar businesses. Sales were up 10% and earnings per share were $0.03 above the range of our forecast. During the quarter, we announced a clear path to profitability in our Energy and Environmental Solutions segment, which to strengthens our company's overall financial outlook, and we expect a strong finish to our fiscal year.
Turning to the industry environment. 2010 has been a very good year for electronic product sales led by consumer demand in the BRIC countries. In the second calendar quarter, our customers saw a year-over-year growth across their end markets, with LCD TV units up 43%, PC units up 20% and cell phones up 15%, led by smartphones.
We're mindful of the soft macroeconomic leading indicators and certainly of leading industry reports. We'll stay close to our customers to anticipate any changes in their markets or investment plans.
Next, I'll cover each of our markets in more detail. For the semiconductor industry, we maintain our WFE spending outlook of $26 billion to $28 billion, the midpoint of which represents growth of 110% for the year. We now expect our equipment sales in SSG and AGS to be up more than 160% for our fiscal year.
The foundries are investing more aggressively than previously expected with significant new orders from a broader set of our customers. Over the first three fiscal quarters, roughly 75% of our orders were concentrated in foundry and DRAM. DRAM pricing is stable, and availability has remained tight with bit supply and demand both growing at 50% to 60%. NAND pricing fell about 5% this quarter and there's been little change all year with supply and demand both growing at 70% to 80%. Overall, memory inventories remain relatively low.
We expect DRAM spending to moderate over the rest of the year, with growth in foundry, NAND and Logic expected to offset the decline. We see NAND investments continuing well into 2011 as demand for flash storage outpaces supply. Q3 was the fifth consecutive growth quarter for SSG and AGS. And today, we're monitoring 15 fabs and fab expansion projects that are projected to add $50 billion in new spending over the next eight to 12 quarters.
In SSG, our focus on capturing new opportunities at key market inflections is paying off. During the quarter, we won significant customer decisions in metal gate transistors, copper interconnects and wafer level packaging. We remain confident that we'll gain two points of WFE share for the year, driven by net positional wins across our portfolio and favorable exposure to the increase in foundry spending.
Sales growth for the year is being led by Etch, where we're tracking the four points of share gains, even as DRAM spending is expected to moderate in the second half of the year. In inspection, we see shifts in the timing of key customer spending and orders for Brightfield and mask inspection are projected to be at record levels in Q4.
Our CMP business had a record sales quarter with share growth led by Reflexion GT, wins at key foundry and memory customers. Semitool booked record orders this quarter and won new copper interconnect positions at three major customers with two wins at advanced nodes and foundry, and another win at a leading edge in memory.
Share gains at Applied and other leading equipment companies are, in effect, consolidating the industry despite limited merger and acquisition activity. Over the past four quarters, total share at the top five equipment companies has grown from under 60% to nearly 70% of WFE. In services, AGS had substantial growth in 200-millimeter used-equipment orders with overall revenue growing in line with a modest uptick in fab utilization.
Moving to the LCD industry, TV shipments grew to 44 million units in the second quarter, which benefited from World Cup demand. Panel makers ran at higher utilization levels in the quarter and reported a week's worth of excess inventory in retail, and that's including in China, which had a seasonal decline of 18%. The current outlook is for these inventories to be absorbed in Q3, and we now believe LCD equipment spending will be 75% to 80% higher for the year, which is above our previous forecast. 
Applied is winning in CVD and color filter PVD, and we're competing very effectively for the new projects in China. Our PiVot PVD is gaining traction, we now have 50% share of the leading customer. We also see touch screens taking off in tablet PCs and smartphones, which is generating growth opportunities in PVD and some modest new opportunities in web.
In the solar industry, worldwide panel installations are trending above 12 gigawatts for the year, driven by pull-ins related to the feed-in tariff in Germany. It's likely that Germany's growth will moderate in 2011, but we see panel demand increasing next year with strength in Europe, China, Japan and parts of the U.S. Fab utilization has improved throughout the crystalline silicon supply chain. Panel ASPs remain stable. Leading panel makers reported sold-out conditions through the end of the year, with visibility into the first half of 2011.
We believe crystalline silicon capacity additions will be in a range of 11 to 13 gigawatts for the year, which is up about 80%. Crystalline silicon equipment spending is likely to double from last year to about $8 billion. While early indications for 2011 are positive, we'll keep a close eye on equipment demand as this year's capacity is absorbed by the industry.
Over time, we expect ratable reductions in panel prices to continue, resulting in a market that is less dependent on government support. Applied had a record profitability in crystalline silicon solar this quarter, led by the highest ever sales at Baccini Cell Systems. Baccini is the platform of choice in China, which is driving 60% of the world's capacity addition this year. We're pleased with our product roadmap, which we see driving further reductions in cost per watt over the next several years.
In summary, Q3 resulted in strong performance across our Semiconductor, Display and Crystalline Silicon Solar businesses, and we expect revenues to be higher in Q4. The macro signals have become more cautious, yet the summer is often a time of concern for our customers. We have not seen a pause in semiconductor capital investment, and we expect a solid finish to our year. I'm also confident that the structural improvements we've made in 2010 will improve Applied's financial performance across the range of business scenarios in 2011. 
I'll now hand the call over to George Davis for more details on our results and targets. George?

headline: Applied Materials Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-18-2010
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Mike, and good afternoon to everyone on the call. Applied results exceeded our revised earnings target range by $0.03 per share, reflecting strong performance across our businesses. Orders grew 8% to $2.7 billion, resulting in the highest qua
componenttext:
Thank you, Mike, and good afternoon to everyone on the call. Applied results exceeded our revised earnings target range by $0.03 per share, reflecting strong performance across our businesses. 
Orders grew 8% to $2.7 billion, resulting in the highest quarterly order levels since the year 2000. Our order outlook continues to appear strong. Backlog increased nearly 5% to $3.1 billion. 
Net sales grew 10% surpassing the high end of our target driven by better-than-expected crystalline silicon and semiconductor equipment sales. GAAP gross margin was 34% for the quarter and was negatively impacted by 10 margin points as a result of the EES inventory-related charges. Excluding those charges, gross margin would've been 44%. 
Non-GAAP operating expenses were in-line with our target at $538 million. In the fourth quarter, we expect to remain near the upper end of our $520 million to $540 million range, as savings initiatives partially offset increases associated with the growth in the business. 
Non-GAAP net income was $0.17 per share. For the purposes of your models, our current results included $0.12 per share of inventory-related charges. Adjusting for these effects, we would have achieved non-GAAP earnings of $0.29 per share against our original target range of $0.22 to $0.26 per share, a very strong quarter for ongoing businesses.
Operating cash flow was $299 million or 12% of sales, reflecting increases in working capital to support the current business. We used $100 million to buy back 7.9 million shares and paid $94 million in dividends, including an increase in our quarterly dividend to $0.07 per share.
Cash and investments grew slightly to over $3.6 billion. Year-to-date, we have generated $1.2 billion of operating cash flow, which is approximately 18% of revenues. I'll now comment on our operating segments.
Silicon Systems Group orders grew 8%, with all applications higher, except DRAM. We expect to see strong bookings again in our fourth quarter, with foundry and Logic orders leading the mix. Semitool had excellent performance with record orders, and the business was accretive to our results. 
SSG net sales grew 3% sequentially and are up 191% year-on-year. Operating margins improved to over 36% in the quarter. AGS orders grew over 23% led by strong demand for 200-millimeter refurbished equipment. Operating margin decreased modestly due to ramp challenges, but we expect improvement in the fourth quarter as our supply chain works through some materials constraints to deliver on increasing 200-millimeter systems demand. For the fiscal year, we still expect AGS revenue to be 35% above 2009.
Display results were once again solid even as orders and revenue declined with expectations. Orders of $242 million were down 6% and net sales were down 20% at $216 million. Display operating margins remained healthy at just under 30% as we realized the benefits of our shift to the Taiwan manufacturing center. 
During the quarter, we shipped more than 90% of our large area deposition equipment from the Tainan facility. For the fiscal year, we now believe Display net sales will improve to more than 70% relative to 2009.
In our Energy and Environmental Solutions segment, orders remained at high levels and revenue more than doubled, reflecting the very strong demand for equipment from our crystalline solar customers. Orders of $353 million were down 7%, but still represent the third highest booking quarter for EES, despite the absence of any thin film orders. Net sales were $387 million, an increase of 133%. 
Our Baccini business was particularly robust as net sales from that group were more than 75% above the previous high achieved in the fourth quarter of 2008. We also recognized revenue on a single-junction SunFab line. Our thin film solar backlog ended the period at about $300 million, with two more factory sign-offs expected over the next two quarters.
The $405 million EES restructuring charge consisted of inventory-related charges of approximately $250 million, and severance and asset impairment charges of $155 million. The inventory-related charges were reported in cost of sales and had a 10-point impact on overall gross margin. The other charges were reported in operating expenses, net of a $20 million favorable adjustment to the restructuring plan announced last November. 
We expect the benefits of the EES restructuring to be reflected in the segment's results over the next three quarters. EES will maintain a modest investment in advanced thin film technology, while upgrades and services for existing SunFab customers will be managed through AGS.
Next, I'll share our outlook for the fourth quarter. We anticipate another strong quarter despite some caution around the potential impact of the softening macroeconomic conditions. We expect Silicon Systems Group net sales to be in-line with the third quarter, and we see preliminary indications from customers that SSG will grow in our first quarter of fiscal 2011. AGS net sales are expected to be up more than 10%, largely due to increased shipments of refurbished equipment and growth in wafer starts. 
In Display, we believe net sales will be up approximately 20% in-line with strong second half investment by Display customers. We expect EES net sales to be down 10% to 20%, but still reflective of strong crystalline solar equipment demand. Upside to this number is possible, if we achieve customer acceptance for a major SunFab factory in China during the quarter. 
Overall, we expect the company's net sales in our fourth quarter to be flat to up 5%. We expect our non-GAAP quarterly earnings per share to be between $0.28 and $0.32 per share. 
With these fourth quarter targets, we also have a clear picture of our full year performance. We expect revenue to be in the range of $9.2 billion to $9.3 billion for the fiscal year, up over 80% versus 2009, with non-GAAP net income in the range of $0.80 to $0.84 per share. Adjusting your models to remove the year-to-date EES inventory-related charges would reflect fiscal year 2010 performance of between $0.96 and $1 per share.
So in summary, we see a very strong finish to an excellent fiscal year. Now Mike, let's open the call for questions.
