headline: Applied Materials Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 17, 2010
componenttextpreview: Please note that today's call will contain forward-looking statements, which are all statements other than those of historical fact, including statements regarding Applied's performance, momentum, strategic positions, operational improvements, products, m
componenttext:
Please note that today's call will contain forward-looking statements, which are all statements other than those of historical fact, including statements regarding Applied's performance, momentum, strategic positions, operational improvements, products, market and industry outlook and Q1 and fiscal 2011 forecast. All forward-looking statements are subject to known and unknown risk and uncertainties that could cause actual results to differ materially from those expressed or implied by such statements. Information concerning these risk factors is contained in today's earnings press release and in the company's filings with the SEC, including its most recent Form 10-Q. Forward-looking statements are based on information as of November 17, 2010, and Applied assumes no obligation to update such statements.
Today's call also contains non-GAAP financial measures, both historical and forecasted. Reconciliations of the GAAP and non-GAAP measures are contained in today's earnings release or in the financial highlights slide, which are available on the Investor page of Applied's website at appliedmaterials.com.
I would now like to turn the conference over to Michael Sullivan, Vice President of Investor Relations. Please go ahead, sir.

headline: Applied Materials Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 17, 2010
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Carrie, and good afternoon. Today, we'll be discussing Applied results for the fourth quarter and the 2010 fiscal year, which ended on October 31. Our earnings release was issued at 1:03 Pacific Time, and you can find a copy on Business Wire an
componenttext:
Thank you, Carrie, and good afternoon. Today, we'll be discussing Applied results for the fourth quarter and the 2010 fiscal year, which ended on October 31. Our earnings release was issued at 1:03 Pacific Time, and you can find a copy on Business Wire and on our website at appliedmaterials.com.
Joining me today are Mike Splinter, our Chairman and CEO; George Davis, our Chief Financial Officer; and Joe Sweeney, our General Counsel and Corporate Secretary. Mike Splinter will be off the call with comments about the industry environment, as well as our performance and plans. George will follow with his comments on our financial results for the quarter and the year, along with our expectations entering fiscal 2011. We have a lot of ground to cover today but we'll be sure there will be plenty of time for your questions. 
And with that, I'd now like to turn the call over to Mike Splinter.

headline: Applied Materials Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 17, 2010
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Mike, and good afternoon to everyone on the call today. I'm pleased to report that Applied ended our fiscal year with an outstanding fourth quarter and enter 2011 with positive momentum. In the fourth quarter, we grew revenue to $2.9 billion, gene
componenttext:
Thanks, Mike, and good afternoon to everyone on the call today. I'm pleased to report that Applied ended our fiscal year with an outstanding fourth quarter and enter 2011 with positive momentum. In the fourth quarter, we grew revenue to $2.9 billion, generated $700 million in operating profit and delivered earnings that exceeded the high end of our target.
Reflecting on the year as a whole, I'm pleased with the progress we've made against our strategic plan. Our goals for 2010 were clear: capitalize on the recovery in our markets, gain share in our core businesses and achieve a new level of operating performance and profitability. We delivered in all three of these areas.
We took advantage of the recovery in semiconductor and display equipment, with revenue growth and an expected two points of share gain in wafer fab equipment spending. We took aggressive actions to restructure our Solar Business, which enabled the EES to achieve profitability in the fourth quarter. In addition, we made operational improvements throughout the organization that make us more efficient. These changes included opening new operation centers in Singapore and Taiwan that are already improving customer delivery and gross margins. 
Before I comment on the upcoming year, I'd like to thank the entire Applied Materials team for their outstanding achievements during 2010.
While we are mindful of the fragile state of the global economy, we have a positive view of the markets we serve and expect the fundamental drivers of 2010 to remain in place next year. We see demand for consumer electronics remaining strong, led by the emerging markets. PC sales are projected to grow 5% to 10%, smartphones are forecast approach 400 million units, LCD TVs reaching 215 million units and tablets are expected to grow to 50 million units or greater. 
Tablets are also leading the transition to solid-state storage. And as a result, we expect NAND bit growth to be in the range of 80% to 90% next year. This is projected to support more than $6 billion of equipment spending, and NAND investment will likely suppress DRAM for the first time. 
In semiconductor equipment, we see PCs as the biggest swing factor in our wafer fab equipment forecast for next year. 
We also see continued strength in Solar, where installations are on track to grow at 20% to 30% in 2011. This growth is being driven by solid project returns even as feed-in tariffs decline.
Let me now turn to each of our segments. In Semiconductor, we expect WFE spending to finish this calendar year in the range of $29 billion to $30 billion, which is above our previous view of $26 billion to $28 billion. We anticipate next year's spending to be in line with 2010, plus or minus 10%. 
Looking further ahead, we are now tracking 17 new fabs and fab expansion projects that represent about $60 billion of equipment spending over the next eight to 12 quarters. We expect next year's foundry and logic spending to remain solid, with an acceleration in NAND helping to offset a pause in DRAM investment. 
NAND provides a number of market inflections that Applied can leverage to win further share. These customers were the first to adopt double patterning, which has enabled us to gain positional wins with our mask and Brightfield inspection products. Recent double patterning etch wins would also contribute to our anticipated share growth next year. And as NAND makers transitioning to the 3x node, our full-blown CBD solution would be the key enabler for their multilevel cell architectures. 
SSG exits 2010 with momentum, and we are on track to increase share in every one of our served markets. We expect to gain two points of share in overall WFE spending, which equates to roughly $600 million of revenue.
We are especially pleased with our traction in Etch, where we won a number of strategic orders and expect four points of share gain this year. In PVD, we're increasing our position across all applications, including copper barrier/seed. And we had key production wins in the rapid growing metal gate area. 
In addition, CMP and Semitool achieved revenue records in the fourth quarter. Our share gains are being fueled by new product innovations, including 12 new products introduced over the past 12 months. And next year, we expect about 20% of our revenue to come from these products.
We are particularly excited about our leadership in the rapidly growing wafer-level packaging market, where we have one over 2/3 of the advanced packaging decisions this year. In 2011, we anticipate wafer starts to increase by approximately 4% year-over-year and our global services business to grow faster when wafer starts. We are earning a larger share of business in Asia, a region that has traditionally been a challenge for service penetration. 
In Display, we expect CapEx for 2010 to be 75% to 80% higher than in 2009. And in Q4, our Display group delivered one of the best quarters in its history.
As the holiday season approaches, we are seeing weakness in the end markets. TV makers are cutting prices to reduce inventory levels. And we expect LCD CapEx to be down more than 20% next year. However, we believe we can outperform this overall trend with continued share gains in PVD and revenue growth from touch panel and OLED products. Touch panel equipment alone represents a $200 million market opportunity next year.
In EES, the fourth quarter was a tremendous end to a record year for our Baccini and PWS businesses. Both businesses surpassed their previous peaks for quarterly revenues and orders. And we expect this record performance to be eclipsed in the first quarter of 2011. 
Demand in the solar market remains extremely robust. We now believe panel installations will reach 16 gigawatts for the calendar year and expect 2011 installations to be in the 19 to 21 gigawatt range. The top panel manufacturers are running at full utilization and are still adding capacity. 
Following a year that exceeded our expectations, we are projecting Solar CapEx for 2011 to be approximately flat year-over-year, in the range of 13 to 15 gigawatts, with each gigawatt of capacity representing over $200 million of equipment opportunity for Applied Materials.
China and Taiwan drove three quarters of this year's crystalline silicon capacity addition and now constitutes 65% of capacity worldwide. Applied has higher market share in China. Then in the rest of the world, service trend bodes well for our business. 
In summary, the fourth quarter was a strong finish to an excellent year for Applied Materials. We delivered on our objectives and gained market share. We have reached profitability in our Energy and Environmental business and made operational improvements across the company. We increased our R&D spending to $1.1 billion through the year with a pipeline of innovative products. This sets the stage for us to outperform our markets again in 2011. We enter the new year with a strong balance sheet that allows us to fund our innovation, maintain strategic flexibility and return cash to stockholders.
Now let me hand the call over to George who will provide additional details about our performance and our outlook. George?

headline: Applied Materials Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 17, 2010
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Mike, and thanks, everyone, for joining us today. I also want to thank the employees of Applied Materials for their efforts to drive a very strong quarter and year for the company. After a most difficult 2009, our employees around the world ral
componenttext:
Thank you, Mike, and thanks, everyone, for joining us today. I also want to thank the employees of Applied Materials for their efforts to drive a very strong quarter and year for the company. After a most difficult 2009, our employees around the world rallied to meet the challenges of a 90% ramp in revenue, while accelerating new product developments, growing market share and improving the operating performance in all of our businesses.
Now I'll start with a brief summary of our results for the fourth quarter. 
Orders were up 11% over Q3, driven by solar and semi equipment demand. This is our sixth consecutive growth quarter and our highest quarter level in almost 10 years. It is worth noting that China accounted for 32% of the orders, led by our crystalline silicon customers. 
Net sales grew 15%, well above our target range, with stronger-than-expected results in our Solar, Display and Semiconductor Equipment businesses. A SunFab sign-up of $225 million was the largest single contributor to higher-than-expected revenue growth in the quarter. 
Non-GAAP gross margin was 42.5%, up eight points on higher revenue in the absence of the inventory charge taken last quarter. The SunFab sign-up lowered overall gross margin by two points. 
Non-GAAP operating expenses of $516 million were favorable to our target range due to an accelerated reduction of EES thin film-related spending and the favorable impact of some discrete items. We expect non-GAAP operating expenses to be in a range of $500 million to $520 million for the quarter during the first half of 2011, down from our recent quarterly run rate of between $530 million and $540 million. Non-GAAP EPS was $0.36 per share, exceeding the high end of our range by $0.04. The increase was driven primarily by higher net sales and lower spending. The SunFab sign-up contributed approximately $0.02 of incremental earnings per share. 
Operating cash flow was $525 million or 18% of sales. During the quarter, we increased our buyback to $150 million used $93 million to pay a dividend of $0.07 per share.
The Silicon Systems Group had order growth in the quarter of 9% and a book-to-bill ratio of 1.1. Net sales increased 2% to $1.5 billion. Foundry customers once again led investments, with growth in logic offsetting a decline in DRAM spending. We see this mixed pattern continuing into the first half of 2011. Operating margins were strong at 38%, which included some increased R&D investments.
In AGS, orders of $631 million reflected continuing demand for 200-millimeter systems. Net sales were up 10%, in line with expectations. And operating margins continue to be impacted by supply chain issues around 200-millimeter systems. 
The Display group concluded a cyclical growth year for LCD equipment, with its highest net sales quarter of the year at $281 million. As we expected, Display orders were down 27% in the quarter, signaling a period of reduced spending for LCD equipment as customers absorb the 2010 capacity additions. 
EES achieved record orders in revenues in the quarter. The SunFab sign-off and a 25% increase in crystalline silicon equipment were the primary drivers of higher sales. EES now has $861 million in backlog, 85% of which is for crystalline silicon solar equipment. EES became profitable in the quarter and achieved a 14% operating margin.
Next, I'll make a few comments about our 2010 fiscal year performance. 2010 orders and revenue book grew substantially from last year, driven by a recovery in semiconductor and display equipment and continued growth in Solar. We delivered non-GAAP EPS of $0.88 per share, which is equivalent to $1.03 per share when excluding the EES inventory related charges taken in Q2 and Q3. 
For the fiscal year, Silicon Systems Group net sales were up 170%, adding $3.3 billion. And operating profit increased over 800%, reaching almost $1.9 billion. AGS net sales improved 34% to $1.9 billion, in line with wafer starts, higher utilization rates and increased 200-millimeter equipment spending. 
Display net sales rebounded in 2010, up almost 80% year-over-year to $899 million. And during the year, we restructured EES to improve profitability and focus on a rapidly growing Crystalline Silicon business. 
In 2010, Applied generated $1.7 billion in cash from operations after investing more than $1.1 billion in research and development. We also brought back $350 million in shares, increased our dividend by 17% and ended the year with $3.9 billion in cash and investments.
Next, I'll turn to our revenue outlook for fiscal 2011. We currently expect our overall net sales to be flat to modestly higher and within a range of plus or minus 10% year-over-year. We expect SSG net sales to be up modestly in fiscal 2011, primarily due to share gains and within a range of plus or minus 10%. 
While this moderate growth assumes an environment of flat wafer fab equipment investment, our wide range reflects the dependency on continued foundry spending and a second half ramp in NAND capacity additions. We expect spending by DRAM customers to soften considerably during the year. AGS net sales in fiscal 2011 are expected to be up in the range of 10% to 15% year-over-year. We expect the primary drivers to be growth in spare parts and services resulting from wafer start additions.
We expect Display net sales to be down between 20% and 25% versus 2010. This reflects a downcycle in the first half of the year for LCD equipment investment, partially offset by higher investment to support equipment related to OLED and touchscreen-related devices. Upside to our sales forecast is possible with an acceleration of the LCD build-out in China.
In EES, we expect 2011 net sales to be down in the range of 20% to 30%. The major factor in the decreased outlook is the absence of any material revenue related to thin film solar. We are entering fiscal 2011 with strong demand for crystalline silicon solar equipment in the first half of the year. At this level, we expect EES to achieve above the post-restructuring model of greater than 10% operating margin throughout the year.
We expect our effective tax rate to drop four to five points from our 2010 rate of 32.4% as a result of the continuing phase-in of our Asian supply chain. 
Now I will cover our targets for the first quarter of 2011. We expect SSG net sales to be approximately flat, with risk in upside relatively balanced. AGS net sales are expected to be up modestly despite softening utilization rates. In Display, we believe net sales will be down approximately 40% as customers pause in line with end market softness. The first half of fiscal 2011 is expected to be a relatively weak period for LCD investments. 
We expect EES net sales to be down approximately 30% from Q4, which benefited from $225 million in SunFab revenue. Sales of crystalline solar equipment are expected to be up more than 10% in the quarter as the investment ramp continues in that market. 
Overall, we expect our Q1 net sales to be down between 8% and 15%. The absence of the large SunFab sign-up has an 8% impact quarter-over-quarter, and the lower Display outlook is about a 4% incremental impact. 
We expect non-GAAP EPS to be in the range of $0.30 to $0.34. In short, we see Q1 being a solid start to what we expect will be a strong fiscal year for Applied Materials. 
Now, Mike, let's open the call for questions.

headline: Applied Materials Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 17, 2010

headline: Applied Materials Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 17, 2010

componenttext: [Operator Instructions] And your first question comes from C.J. Muse with Barclays Capital.

headline: Applied Materials Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 17, 2010
componenttextpreview: I guess within that, on the WFE plus or minus 10% for fiscal '11, can you talk a little bit about what kind of expected linearity you see throughout the year?
componenttext: I guess within that, on the WFE plus or minus 10% for fiscal '11, can you talk a little bit about what kind of expected linearity you see throughout the year?

headline: Applied Materials Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 17, 2010
componenttextpreview: Well, I think we have pretty good visibility of the Q1, C.J. But I think the things to look for, and I'll just tell you how we're looking at kind of the indicators we're looking at, the first one really is PCs. PC, it still drives a huge amount of the DRA
componenttext: Well, I think we have pretty good visibility of the Q1, C.J. But I think the things to look for, and I'll just tell you how we're looking at kind of the indicators we're looking at, the first one really is PCs. PC, it still drives a huge amount of the DRAM capacity. We cannot target -- our view of flat WFE at about a 7% growth in PCs. And the percent growth versus percent of WFE is almost a 1:1 kind of relationship. So if PCs were up in the 10% to 15% range, we'd expect WFE to be up. The other thing we're really looking closely at is tablets because tablets and smartphones drive NAND spending. We're expecting 50 million tablets and 350 million or 400 million smartphones. That's kind of our flat scenario, more than that would drive higher wafer fab equipment spending. As George talked about, we think Q1 SSG will be pretty strong modestly, flat to up. So that kind of tells you how we see the start of the year, at least January start of the year, in WFE.

headline: Applied Materials Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 17, 2010
componenttextpreview: And as a quick follow-up, considering kind of the range that you expect across divisions, what kind of gross margin profile should we expect relative to the 42% you printed in fiscal '10?
componenttext: And as a quick follow-up, considering kind of the range that you expect across divisions, what kind of gross margin profile should we expect relative to the 42% you printed in fiscal '10?

headline: Applied Materials Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 17, 2010
componenttextpreview: I think the way to think about gross margin is we've obviously had a lot of noise in it in both '09 from just the environment, and '10 from the restructuring of EES. We said that we would have been up two points, so in the 44-plus percent range this quart
componenttext: I think the way to think about gross margin is we've obviously had a lot of noise in it in both '09 from just the environment, and '10 from the restructuring of EES. We said that we would have been up two points, so in the 44-plus percent range this quarter if we had not have the SunFab sign up. That's probably a reasonable starting point, and then it will be a mix effect from the there on.

headline: Applied Materials Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 17, 2010
componenttextpreview: So our next question comes from Atif Malik with Morgan Stanley.
componenttext: So our next question comes from Atif Malik with Morgan Stanley.

headline: Applied Materials Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 17, 2010
componenttextpreview: My question is on the services side. George, you guys are doing quite well in terms of operating margins in other segments and kind of exceeding your prior peak levels in 2007. But on services, you mentioned there are some supply chain issues on 200-milli
componenttext: My question is on the services side. George, you guys are doing quite well in terms of operating margins in other segments and kind of exceeding your prior peak levels in 2007. But on services, you mentioned there are some supply chain issues on 200-millimeter. So as we see your sales growing 10% to 15% next year, can you help us understand where the operating margins for that business could be next year?

headline: Applied Materials Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 17, 2010
componenttextpreview: Sure. Obviously, we improved somewhat this quarter over the previous quarter, but we're still well behind where we want to be in terms of our operating model for the second half of 2011. We're still though working with a cold supply chain and incurring a
componenttext: Sure. Obviously, we improved somewhat this quarter over the previous quarter, but we're still well behind where we want to be in terms of our operating model for the second half of 2011. We're still though working with a cold supply chain and incurring a relatively significant additional cost to support our customers. So we think it's going to take another quarter or two to get through this issue, and then you should start seeing three to four points or more of operating margin pick up with the same level of revenue.

headline: Applied Materials Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 17, 2010
componenttextpreview: And a quick follow-up, on the $600 million revenue that you expect from two percentage points of share gain in the Silicon segment, can you help us understand how much of that is being NAND driven, as the devices move to 3x nanometer and new Applied benef
componenttext: And a quick follow-up, on the $600 million revenue that you expect from two percentage points of share gain in the Silicon segment, can you help us understand how much of that is being NAND driven, as the devices move to 3x nanometer and new Applied benefit for how much that position for our product portfolio there? So how much of the $600 million are from NAND contribution?

headline: Applied Materials Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 17, 2010
componenttextpreview: That's a pretty hard question to answer, Atif. I think the way we're looking at this is in the scenario -- because you can do a million scenarios. But as I said, we're expecting flash to be about $6 billion, let's say out of the $30 billion. So DRAM is al
componenttext: That's a pretty hard question to answer, Atif. I think the way we're looking at this is in the scenario -- because you can do a million scenarios. But as I said, we're expecting flash to be about $6 billion, let's say out of the $30 billion. So DRAM is almost the same. We're expecting foundry to be up a bit. So our specific share in flash is off our average WFE share, but our specific share in foundry is above our WFE shares. So these things kind of balance out overall.

headline: Applied Materials Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 17, 2010
componenttextpreview: Also, the 2% related to 2010, that reflects the mix of business that we saw, which was lighter in NAND overall than we would expect to see in 2011.
componenttext: Also, the 2% related to 2010, that reflects the mix of business that we saw, which was lighter in NAND overall than we would expect to see in 2011.

headline: Applied Materials Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 17, 2010
componenttextpreview: But we do expect to gain more than a point of share versus WFE in 2011, which would be two points or more than two points in our markets.
componenttext: But we do expect to gain more than a point of share versus WFE in 2011, which would be two points or more than two points in our markets.

headline: Applied Materials Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 17, 2010
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from Jim Covello with Goldman Sachs.
componenttext: Your next question comes from Jim Covello with Goldman Sachs.

headline: Applied Materials Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 17, 2010
componenttextpreview: So when you talk about NAND ramping in the second half of next year, I mean, can you talk a little bit about the dynamic there of -- do you think the existing NAND capacity can satisfy the early part of the tablet ramp as we go through next year, and then
componenttext: So when you talk about NAND ramping in the second half of next year, I mean, can you talk a little bit about the dynamic there of -- do you think the existing NAND capacity can satisfy the early part of the tablet ramp as we go through next year, and then its incremental tablets to driving that incremental NAND spend? Or if you could talk a little about the dynamics on that, that would be great.

headline: Applied Materials Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 17, 2010
componenttextpreview: Well, we just think second half will be greater than the first half. It's not that there isn't investment in the first half. But in particular, we think we'll see the major part of a major factory in Japan ramping up in the second half. So that's really t
componenttext: Well, we just think second half will be greater than the first half. It's not that there isn't investment in the first half. But in particular, we think we'll see the major part of a major factory in Japan ramping up in the second half. So that's really the major effect there. But other additions will happen, as a matter and of course, in the first half of the year. In 2010, flash spending was $4 billion, so we'll certainly see that kind of run rate pretty much continuing, grow through the year.

headline: Applied Materials Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 17, 2010
componenttextpreview: I see. And so could you see orders ramping over the next few quarters and then it's the shipments that ramp in the latter part of next year? Is that the idea?
componenttext: I see. And so could you see orders ramping over the next few quarters and then it's the shipments that ramp in the latter part of next year? Is that the idea?

headline: Applied Materials Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 17, 2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, that's the idea.
componenttext: Yes, that's the idea.

headline: Applied Materials Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 17, 2010

componenttext: Your next question comes from Satya Kumar with Crédit Suisse.

headline: Applied Materials Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 17, 2010
componenttextpreview: Just a quick question on the Solar side, you have seen a significant ramp in orders from Q1 to Q4 for Solar and you're talking about a 12 to 14 gigawatt new capacity additions for the whole year. If I look at Q4 alone, is it fair to say that on a run rate
componenttext: Just a quick question on the Solar side, you have seen a significant ramp in orders from Q1 to Q4 for Solar and you're talking about a 12 to 14 gigawatt new capacity additions for the whole year. If I look at Q4 alone, is it fair to say that on a run rate basis of the new capacity additions are approaching the 18 to 20 gigawatt run rate?

headline: Applied Materials Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 17, 2010
componenttextpreview: I think that's fair, yes, on a run rate basis.
componenttext: I think that's fair, yes, on a run rate basis.

headline: Applied Materials Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 17, 2010
componenttextpreview: In the last conference call, I think you were sounding a little bit more cautious in the sustainability of this, call them, new capacity additions. But it appears that you're looking at a similar capacity addition run rate for fiscal 2011. I was wondering
componenttext: In the last conference call, I think you were sounding a little bit more cautious in the sustainability of this, call them, new capacity additions. But it appears that you're looking at a similar capacity addition run rate for fiscal 2011. I was wondering what trend you are seeing in the customer base that makes you believe that this trend can continue? I think you even mentioned that fiscal Q1 looks better than fiscal Q4.

headline: Applied Materials Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 17, 2010
componenttextpreview: Well, that's obviously the number one trend that our customers have confidence to continue to invest and invest strongly in capacity. And many of the bigger guys are fully loaded and sold out for some extended period of time. So they are adding capacity a
componenttext: Well, that's obviously the number one trend that our customers have confidence to continue to invest and invest strongly in capacity. And many of the bigger guys are fully loaded and sold out for some extended period of time. So they are adding capacity and haven't slowed down a bit. As a retrospective, as I've thought about how I felt a year ago, the situation was kind of the same. The business was strong. It was continuing to go up. And I think we haven't seen the peak yet in Solar. And despite feed-in tariffs continuing to go down, they seem to just spur more investment as the pricing continues to get driven down. I think pricing for modules and installations is going to continue to go down, which will continue to make it like look like a very solid investment.

headline: Applied Materials Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 17, 2010
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from Stephen Chin with UBS.
componenttext: Your next question comes from Stephen Chin with UBS.

headline: Applied Materials Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 17, 2010
componenttextpreview: Just a question on the January quarter silicon sales guidance, I think you said that it would be flat to up slightly sequentially. My question is that the silicon backlog was up another 21% sequentially in this October quarter, so you might argue that the
componenttext: Just a question on the January quarter silicon sales guidance, I think you said that it would be flat to up slightly sequentially. My question is that the silicon backlog was up another 21% sequentially in this October quarter, so you might argue that the January sales guidance could be conservative. Is it conservative just on a maybe less turns business in the Silicon Systems business in the January quarter?

headline: Applied Materials Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 17, 2010
componenttextpreview: No, I think, clearly, we've seen a fair amount of turns business. But you can get pushes and pulls.  Certainly we're seeing, with where DRAM pricing is, you got the holiday season coming up. You got a lot of factors that can cause customers to move things
componenttext: No, I think, clearly, we've seen a fair amount of turns business. But you can get pushes and pulls.  Certainly we're seeing, with where DRAM pricing is, you got the holiday season coming up. You got a lot of factors that can cause customers to move things around. We think with the visibility that we have today, we're comfortable with the flat. That's why we said we kind of see the risk and reward balanced for the quarter. And there's certainly scenarios where it could be up. But that's a pretty concentrated group of customers, so you could also be down as somebody pushes out. Right now, we feel good about the forecast.

headline: Applied Materials Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 17, 2010
componenttextpreview: Maybe I can ask a different question on the EES operating margin. I was wondering, George, if you could share any color on what the normalized operating margin of just the Crystalline Systems business might be since the figure, I think, is hitting well th
componenttext: Maybe I can ask a different question on the EES operating margin. I was wondering, George, if you could share any color on what the normalized operating margin of just the Crystalline Systems business might be since the figure, I think, is hitting well there now. And if you don't want to share the number, is it closer to the silicon margins? Or is it closer to the Display margins? Just trying to get a sense of what this could look like going forward once the SunFab revenue recognition stops.

headline: Applied Materials Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 17, 2010
componenttextpreview: Well, what we've said is we gave a model in July that gave an indication of what it looks like post. And our model was intentionally conservative coming out. So we've said better than 10% operating margins at $1.250 billion quarter run rate. And obviously
componenttext: Well, what we've said is we gave a model in July that gave an indication of what it looks like post. And our model was intentionally conservative coming out. So we've said better than 10% operating margins at $1.250 billion quarter run rate. And obviously, we had a pretty strong quarter this quarter. I think we can do better than the operating model, and we'll continue to watch that through the year. As you know, this business can be volatile. And right now, it looks very strong in the first half of the year, and so we'll just have to see how the second of the year. But we feel very good overall. And if you kind of compare year-over-year, where we had a significant loss in the EES area, we're going to have a high confidence on our profit this year. That's going to be a big swing year-over-year for us.

headline: Applied Materials Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 17, 2010
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from Krish Sankar with Bank of America.
componenttext: Your next question comes from Krish Sankar with Bank of America.

headline: Applied Materials Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 17, 2010
componenttextpreview: Mike, you said that you expect NAND CapEx to be back-half loaded. What is your view on how the foundry CapEx would trend through 2011?
componenttext: Mike, you said that you expect NAND CapEx to be back-half loaded. What is your view on how the foundry CapEx would trend through 2011?

headline: Applied Materials Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 17, 2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, so we think foundry is going to be pretty strong throughout the year leading the way, even up in the first part of the year here a bit. But we think it will be up overall slightly over 2010 and pretty even through the year as the various players fill
componenttext: Yes, so we think foundry is going to be pretty strong throughout the year leading the way, even up in the first part of the year here a bit. But we think it will be up overall slightly over 2010 and pretty even through the year as the various players fill up their fabs.

headline: Applied Materials Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 17, 2010
componenttextpreview: And then a question for George. Given your of fiscal year 2011 guidance and keeping the composition of the revenue as what you said, what do you think would be the OpEx run rate exiting 2011?
componenttext: And then a question for George. Given your of fiscal year 2011 guidance and keeping the composition of the revenue as what you said, what do you think would be the OpEx run rate exiting 2011?

headline: Applied Materials Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 17, 2010
componenttextpreview: Well, what we said is we're going -- the first half of the year, we think the OpEx run rate will be somewhere between $500 million and $520 million. I think we'll just have to see how the second half plays out. We've got a fairly strong variable model as
componenttext: Well, what we said is we're going -- the first half of the year, we think the OpEx run rate will be somewhere between $500 million and $520 million. I think we'll just have to see how the second half plays out. We've got a fairly strong variable model as you know. If we see strength in the second of the year, then I think that's probably a good continuing estimate. But it will get a little bit of help just because we'll continue to have finish up the restructuring of EES over that time period. And if, for some reason, the year is down, we'll be able to take OpEx down a little bit.

headline: Applied Materials Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 17, 2010
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from Peter Kim with Deutsche Bank.
componenttext: Your next question comes from Peter Kim with Deutsche Bank.

headline: Applied Materials Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 17, 2010
componenttextpreview: So the question I wanted to ask about was the EES portion. The crystalline silicon sales in fiscal 2011 to be, just the Silicon segment alone, will be up year-over-year or slightly down?
componenttext: So the question I wanted to ask about was the EES portion. The crystalline silicon sales in fiscal 2011 to be, just the Silicon segment alone, will be up year-over-year or slightly down?

headline: Applied Materials Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 17, 2010
componenttextpreview: For just the crystalline sales?
componenttext: For just the crystalline sales?

headline: Applied Materials Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 17, 2010
componenttextpreview: That's correct.
componenttext: That's correct.

headline: Applied Materials Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 17, 2010
componenttextpreview: Probably, that will be up year-over-year.
componenttext: Probably, that will be up year-over-year.

headline: Applied Materials Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 17, 2010
componenttextpreview: And you expect that to operate at net 114% operating margin?
componenttext: And you expect that to operate at net 114% operating margin?

headline: Applied Materials Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 17, 2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, definitely better than '10.
componenttext: Yes, definitely better than '10.

headline: Applied Materials Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 17, 2010
componenttextpreview: With regards to the 200-millimeter, I mean, it's definitely been very strong for you in the past couple of quarters. I was wondering how long you think that trend could continue? Due you expect that the demand for 200-millimeter to continue to improve yea
componenttext: With regards to the 200-millimeter, I mean, it's definitely been very strong for you in the past couple of quarters. I was wondering how long you think that trend could continue? Due you expect that the demand for 200-millimeter to continue to improve year-over-year? Or do you expect that at some point the 200-millimeter capacity could start to slow down?

headline: Applied Materials Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 17, 2010
componenttextpreview: We think right now we're in a bit of a surge on 200-millimeter capacity because there was so much taken off in 2009. And for MEMS, for power transistors, for solar panels and electric cars, for analog devices or for things like display drivers all need 20
componenttext: We think right now we're in a bit of a surge on 200-millimeter capacity because there was so much taken off in 2009. And for MEMS, for power transistors, for solar panels and electric cars, for analog devices or for things like display drivers all need 200-millimeter, so we think that the market will peak here sometime in 2011 and then come back down to some steady-state rate that's may be off the peak, we'll see in the next few quarters by 10% or 20%, something on that order.

headline: Applied Materials Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 17, 2010
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from Gary Hsueh with Oppenheimer & Co.
componenttext: Your next question comes from Gary Hsueh with Oppenheimer & Co.

headline: Applied Materials Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 17, 2010
componenttextpreview: Mike, I understand that heading into 2011, there's a lot of uncertainties and flat year-over-year kind of spending environment, sort of a non-committal sort of forecast for 2011. But if you took your SSG kind of guidance for Q1, and it's a flat line throu
componenttext: Mike, I understand that heading into 2011, there's a lot of uncertainties and flat year-over-year kind of spending environment, sort of a non-committal sort of forecast for 2011. But if you took your SSG kind of guidance for Q1, and it's a flat line throughout the year. You're looking at a fiscal 2011 that's up well above 10%, let's say more around 15%. So I'm just wondering where do you think the potential pitfalls are in terms of the SSG business, either near term are in the back half of 2011? And my second question is if we're looking at a NAND-heavy spending environment in 2011, I'm wondering if you could kind of take a quick stab at how well you guys could outperform the market in SSG give increasing market share, as you pointed out, and maybe just natural market share being higher for some of these NAND manufacturers?

headline: Applied Materials Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 17, 2010
componenttextpreview: So, yes, if the entire year was like you want it, it would be up quite a bit more than 10%. It's just we're in a bit of an uncertain environment. And the big deal in my mind on this, the big pitfall or potential upside is all around DRAM and PC-related de
componenttext: So, yes, if the entire year was like you want it, it would be up quite a bit more than 10%. It's just we're in a bit of an uncertain environment. And the big deal in my mind on this, the big pitfall or potential upside is all around DRAM and PC-related demand. So we feel like relative to -- we feel we're pretty much on the industry consensus between 5% and 10% in our estimates, that there's obviously been a lot of discussion of bigger numbers from people who know this business well like Intel and AMD. So if WFE stays as strong as it is at the beginning of the year, we'll have a stronger year. But the market is volatile, and it's hard to predict we'll hit 10%, I think. That's the key area and potential pitfall. Our estimate on our share growth is based on both foundry and NAND going up kind of together. We're excited in particular about etch gains in flash memory, that should be a big positive for us, deposition gains of course, as double patterning becomes a bigger part of the process. And one of the areas in 2010 that positively surprised as I think from the beginning of the year was our CMP position. We won a lot of share back in CMP. We have a great new product there, Reflexion GT, that improves productivity as being adopted. And of course, I did want to say that rare earth element constraints in the market are not going to slow down CMP, at least we don't think so. But anyway, that's kind of the picture. I'm not sure I answered all your questions, but maybe you do have a quick follow-up.

headline: Applied Materials Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 17, 2010
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from Patrick Ho with Stifel, Nicolaus.
componenttext: Your next question comes from Patrick Ho with Stifel, Nicolaus.

headline: Applied Materials Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 17, 2010
componenttextpreview: Mike, following off that last question about the market share gains, you mentioned double patterning as being one of the key application drivers for the share wins. Can you just comment, I guess broadly, what other, I guess, process changes or other appli
componenttext: Mike, following off that last question about the market share gains, you mentioned double patterning as being one of the key application drivers for the share wins. Can you just comment, I guess broadly, what other, I guess, process changes or other applications that will help you gain share both this year and into next year?

headline: Applied Materials Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 17, 2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, I'd say really three things. One is the conversion to metal gate at the logic and foundry companies. This has helped our PVD business substantially. The second one is conversion to copper in the memory companies. Semitool has done very well in that m
componenttext: Yes, I'd say really three things. One is the conversion to metal gate at the logic and foundry companies. This has helped our PVD business substantially. The second one is conversion to copper in the memory companies. Semitool has done very well in that market, certainly won more than their standard share by a wide margin. And then the third area is the movement towards wafer-level packaging where we've been able to put together a suite of products there that really help the customers see how the integration of the various processes go together. And we're quite bullish. We kind of added up all the wins in that space over the year. And there were some -- we won basically over 60% of those decisions in our market. And I think there was some 65 decisions across the industry that we counted up this year. So while that market isn't big yet, it really, I think, is a harbinger for positive future for our SSG products.

headline: Applied Materials Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 17, 2010
componenttextpreview: And my follow-up question is kind of longer term and bigger picture. Your flowable CVD product, I think you mentioned when the product was introduced, it's something that's targeting the 2x nanometer and below and it's a $400 million opportunity, is that
componenttext: And my follow-up question is kind of longer term and bigger picture. Your flowable CVD product, I think you mentioned when the product was introduced, it's something that's targeting the 2x nanometer and below and it's a $400 million opportunity, is that something that's still 2012 and beyond where you are targeting? Or do you see any kind of accelerations or pulls into 2011 as you work with your customers?

headline: Applied Materials Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 17, 2010
componenttextpreview: Well, we were think it's the secret to really a small, narrow STI [Shallow Trench Isolation] and to multi-cell performance in flash. So we're starting to see more and more interest in that product. Customers have had to do some extremely difficult integra
componenttext: Well, we were think it's the secret to really a small, narrow STI [Shallow Trench Isolation] and to multi-cell performance in flash. So we're starting to see more and more interest in that product. Customers have had to do some extremely difficult integration schemes with spin-on and CVD depositions to fill those narrow gaps. With this product, you can get away from a lot of that complexity and costs. So there's a lot of interest there. It's too early to say it's a big pull-in into 2011, but we certainly see it being an important product, certainly for DRAM, for flash are getting into logic as well.

headline: Applied Materials Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 17, 2010
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from Timothy Arcuri with Citi.
componenttext: Your next question comes from Timothy Arcuri with Citi.

headline: Applied Materials Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 17, 2010
componenttextpreview: First of all, if I look at your SSG business, you overbooked what you revenued in July, and you overbooked what you revenued in October as well. So if revenue was flat in January, it would seem to upside at bookings and sort of SSG are going to be down so
componenttext: First of all, if I look at your SSG business, you overbooked what you revenued in July, and you overbooked what you revenued in October as well. So if revenue was flat in January, it would seem to upside at bookings and sort of SSG are going to be down something like 20%? Is that sort of right math?

headline: Applied Materials Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 17, 2010
componenttextpreview: No, I do think we're thinking that at all. No.
componenttext: No, I do think we're thinking that at all. No.

headline: Applied Materials Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 17, 2010
componenttextpreview: No, I think it really reflects the combination of starting with a very low backlog and a high turns business.
componenttext: No, I think it really reflects the combination of starting with a very low backlog and a high turns business.

headline: Applied Materials Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 17, 2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, I think our order pattern has dramatically changed from history, Tim. And to read too much into what's in the bookings backlog for SSG is more about who's ordering than the order magnitude itself.
componenttext: Yes, I think our order pattern has dramatically changed from history, Tim. And to read too much into what's in the bookings backlog for SSG is more about who's ordering than the order magnitude itself.

headline: Applied Materials Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 17, 2010
componenttextpreview: So just on that point, so Mike, are you saying that customers are ordering, placing orders now for deliveries like in the second of next year, is that what you're saying?
componenttext: So just on that point, so Mike, are you saying that customers are ordering, placing orders now for deliveries like in the second of next year, is that what you're saying?

headline: Applied Materials Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 17, 2010
componenttextpreview: Other way around. Their ordering for deliveries in this quarter.
componenttext: Other way around. Their ordering for deliveries in this quarter.

headline: Applied Materials Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 17, 2010
componenttextpreview: So if that was the case, then you're booking should sort of more closely match your shipments, right?
componenttext: So if that was the case, then you're booking should sort of more closely match your shipments, right?

headline: Applied Materials Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 17, 2010
componenttextpreview: I think you've been ramping revenues significantly coming out of '09, and you had the turns business combined. And it's highly concentrated in the couple of customers. I mean, the turns business is effectively a process where the few customers, they walk
componenttext: I think you've been ramping revenues significantly coming out of '09, and you had the turns business combined. And it's highly concentrated in the couple of customers. I mean, the turns business is effectively a process where the few customers, they walk down the POs but you've had a lot dialogue, a lot of scheduling, a lot of product configuration. It's just that the way the process, you don't close the traditional order until the quarter in which they shift. And as you know, we have a far more concentrated customer base and so you get some of these patterns that you are looking for.

headline: Applied Materials Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 17, 2010
componenttextpreview: Just on the modeling of AGS. Before, you had said something like 24% to 26% operating margin at the $2 billion revenue run rate. And it seems like you're 400 to 500 basis points below that model. Is that just sort of a catch-up that we'll see next year or
componenttext: Just on the modeling of AGS. Before, you had said something like 24% to 26% operating margin at the $2 billion revenue run rate. And it seems like you're 400 to 500 basis points below that model. Is that just sort of a catch-up that we'll see next year or is there something going on in AGS that's sort of causing you to be shy of that model?

headline: Applied Materials Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 17, 2010
componenttextpreview: No, as we've said, we're shy of where we should be against the model because of the 200-millimeter shipment issues that we're having and it really is all out of the supply chain. So I agree, we're operating at least a three to four points, maybe three poi
componenttext: No, as we've said, we're shy of where we should be against the model because of the 200-millimeter shipment issues that we're having and it really is all out of the supply chain. So I agree, we're operating at least a three to four points, maybe three points today below where I'd like to see us, and then that widens out a little bit by the end of next year where we said we would have flown through a lot of the kind of transformational restructuring activities in AGS. So you would see the full model in place. We said we're not at the second half of '11 yet where we said all those models will be in place. But we're not where we would like to be right now there, and we're working on it.

headline: Applied Materials Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 17, 2010
componenttextpreview: So our next question comes from Edwin Mok with Needman (sic) [Needham &  Company].
componenttext: So our next question comes from Edwin Mok with Needman (sic) [Needham &  Company].

headline: Applied Materials Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 17, 2010
componenttextpreview: So just a question on your orders that you print, I noticed that the orders from the kind of logic/auto customer has constantly high-level, probably one of the highest fourth week in it, I ask why that's the case? Is that tied to more 200-millimeter that
componenttext: So just a question on your orders that you print, I noticed that the orders from the kind of logic/auto customer has constantly high-level, probably one of the highest fourth week in it, I ask why that's the case? Is that tied to more 200-millimeter that some specific customers are ordering?

componenttextpreview: Primarily one large logic customer that's placing a number of orders, yes.
componenttext: Primarily one large logic customer that's placing a number of orders, yes.

headline: Applied Materials Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 17, 2010
componenttextpreview: Then I have a follow-up question on your Display business. You mentioned that you guys have on your product, that's PVD product, you mentioned share gain in that area, baking into your full year guidance of Display down 20% to 25%, that's roughly in line
componenttext: Then I have a follow-up question on your Display business. You mentioned that you guys have on your product, that's PVD product, you mentioned share gain in that area, baking into your full year guidance of Display down 20% to 25%, that's roughly in line with what you said will be their end market, are you proud to think that there's a limit room to gain further share on PVD? Or am I reading too much into that guidance versus your own business?

headline: Applied Materials Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 17, 2010
componenttextpreview: I think you're reading too much into the guidance. I said we think this play be down, the market will be down more than 20%. And we were talking specifically about our guidance for 2011, the 20% to 25%. So I wouldn't read into it. We think we've got a goo
componenttext: I think you're reading too much into the guidance. I said we think this play be down, the market will be down more than 20%. And we were talking specifically about our guidance for 2011, the 20% to 25%. So I wouldn't read into it. We think we've got a good PVD product. It's going to continue to gain share, and we would expect the whole share in our other major products at a minimum.

headline: Applied Materials Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 17, 2010
componenttextpreview: And we have opportunity ahead with touch panels and OLED as another positive trend there. And we're just reacting to the weak TV market that we've been seeing recently.
componenttext: And we have opportunity ahead with touch panels and OLED as another positive trend there. And we're just reacting to the weak TV market that we've been seeing recently.

headline: Applied Materials Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 17, 2010
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from Mehdi Hosseini with Susquehanna International.
componenttext: Your next question comes from Mehdi Hosseini with Susquehanna International.

headline: Applied Materials Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 17, 2010
componenttextpreview: Mike, I'm a little bit confused. In your prepared remarks, you said NAND spending is going to be about $6 billion or even higher than that. And then that's going to be higher than DRAM CapEx next year?
componenttext: Mike, I'm a little bit confused. In your prepared remarks, you said NAND spending is going to be about $6 billion or even higher than that. And then that's going to be higher than DRAM CapEx next year?

headline: Applied Materials Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 17, 2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, potentially it will be higher than the DRAM CapEx, which we think be off a bit from where it is, just slightly lower than flash.
componenttext: Yes, potentially it will be higher than the DRAM CapEx, which we think be off a bit from where it is, just slightly lower than flash.

headline: Applied Materials Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 17, 2010
componenttextpreview: So if DRAM is going to be less than $6 billion and you're suggesting that WFE is going to be flat, then where will the $5 billion, $6 billion, $10 billion decline in DRAM spending going to be offset from?
componenttext: So if DRAM is going to be less than $6 billion and you're suggesting that WFE is going to be flat, then where will the $5 billion, $6 billion, $10 billion decline in DRAM spending going to be offset from?

headline: Applied Materials Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 17, 2010
componenttextpreview: I'll just give you the numbers we're working with so that we avoid the confusion. We think DRAM spent $8.5 billion in 2010. We think it will be down to roughly $6 billion. NAND spent $4 billion dollars in 2010 and it will be up to over $6 billion. So thos
componenttext: I'll just give you the numbers we're working with so that we avoid the confusion. We think DRAM spent $8.5 billion in 2010. We think it will be down to roughly $6 billion. NAND spent $4 billion dollars in 2010 and it will be up to over $6 billion. So those two, on a gross basis pretty much balance out. And then we think foundry will be up to give a flat overall market.

headline: Applied Materials Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 17, 2010
componenttextpreview: And then just as a follow-up, where are we going to hear any update on the LED front?
componenttext: And then just as a follow-up, where are we going to hear any update on the LED front?

headline: Applied Materials Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 17, 2010
componenttextpreview: We're working with some key customers, and we're getting increased interest. But they are starting to really see the uniqueness of our product. And when that product has met all of its requirements, we'll introduce it, but not till then.
componenttext: We're working with some key customers, and we're getting increased interest. But they are starting to really see the uniqueness of our product. And when that product has met all of its requirements, we'll introduce it, but not till then.

headline: Applied Materials Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 17, 2010
componenttextpreview: Should I assume that this is a strategy by you to make sure that the product acceptance, penetration is in full force before coming out public? It's somewhat contrast to what happened to SunFab, or is it a reflection of maybe some challenges or longer-tha
componenttext: Should I assume that this is a strategy by you to make sure that the product acceptance, penetration is in full force before coming out public? It's somewhat contrast to what happened to SunFab, or is it a reflection of maybe some challenges or longer-than-expected acceptance?

headline: Applied Materials Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 17, 2010
componenttextpreview: No, I think we just want to make sure that the product that the want, these products are complex, and process has to meet the requirement that the customers have and provide uniqueness to garner its to value in the marketplace. So I wouldn't read a whole
componenttext: No, I think we just want to make sure that the product that the want, these products are complex, and process has to meet the requirement that the customers have and provide uniqueness to garner its to value in the marketplace. So I wouldn't read a whole lot into it besides that.

headline: Applied Materials Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 17, 2010
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from Brian Lee with JPMorgan.
componenttext: Your next question comes from Brian Lee with JPMorgan.

headline: Applied Materials Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 17, 2010
componenttextpreview: I guess last quarter you provided guidance for the quarter but also some qualitative color around SSG shipments being up in fiscal Q1 versus Q4. Do you have that same level of visibility today to provide the same sort of qualitative color for fiscal Q2 re
componenttext: I guess last quarter you provided guidance for the quarter but also some qualitative color around SSG shipments being up in fiscal Q1 versus Q4. Do you have that same level of visibility today to provide the same sort of qualitative color for fiscal Q2 relative to Q1?

headline: Applied Materials Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 17, 2010
componenttextpreview: No, I think we had just such a very strong indication and a couple of projects where it was just very clear that we would have a strong Q1 that we went out and gave that picture. Also, we felt at that time there was some confusion about whether we would b
componenttext: No, I think we had just such a very strong indication and a couple of projects where it was just very clear that we would have a strong Q1 that we went out and gave that picture. Also, we felt at that time there was some confusion about whether we would be experiencing an immediate drop off, and we just didn't see that. So we don't have -- I'd say it's not a function of having no visibility for our fiscal Q2, but we're just going to stick with the Q1 guidance.

headline: Applied Materials Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 17, 2010
componenttextpreview: And then as a follow-up, I guess, on the operating margin for EES, I know you talked about the two-point impact to the overall gross margin from the SunFab sign-up. What would operating margin for EES have been in the quarter if we exclude the impact to S
componenttext: And then as a follow-up, I guess, on the operating margin for EES, I know you talked about the two-point impact to the overall gross margin from the SunFab sign-up. What would operating margin for EES have been in the quarter if we exclude the impact to SunFab?

headline: Applied Materials Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 17, 2010
componenttextpreview: I haven't broken that out, but the margin would have clearly been up relative to the 14% reported. It was a very, very strong quarter overall. So again, we're not breaking out the individual operating margins at that level. But again, we would expect anot
componenttext: I haven't broken that out, but the margin would have clearly been up relative to the 14% reported. It was a very, very strong quarter overall. So again, we're not breaking out the individual operating margins at that level. But again, we would expect another similarly strong quarter next quarter.

headline: Applied Materials Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 17, 2010

componenttext: Your next question comes from Mahesh Sanganeria with RBC Capital Markets.

componenttext: George, you talked about $300 million in thin films revenue and you said you recognized $225 million to SunFab, is there some more, is there $74 million, $75 million more that you need to recognize in January quarter?

componenttext: No, we have one remaining SunFab factory that's not signed off. It's very small, relatively speaking. We are talking to some of our existing SunFab customers about equipment to upgrade certain other facilities, but we haven't forecasted any of those projects at this point.

headline: Applied Materials Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 17, 2010
componenttextpreview: And quickly, if I take your yearly guidance for EES and order you just reported, it looks like that there it will be pretty linearly declining, first because of the impact of the SunFab, but even crystalline looks like you need to decline a lot to get to
componenttext: And quickly, if I take your yearly guidance for EES and order you just reported, it looks like that there it will be pretty linearly declining, first because of the impact of the SunFab, but even crystalline looks like you need to decline a lot to get to your down 25%. headline: Applied Materials Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 17, 2010
componenttextpreview: I think you probably have too low a number for thin film-related revenue, which was about $500 million last year. So if you make that adjustment, you'll see that at the low end it's kind of flat and then it comes up from there.
componenttext: I think you probably have too low a number for thin film-related revenue, which was about $500 million last year. So if you make that adjustment, you'll see that at the low end it's kind of flat and then it comes up from there.

headline: Applied Materials Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 17, 2010
componenttextpreview: Well, traditionally, OLED has been for smaller form factor experience for smartphones, cell phones and those kind of applications, so most of the factories are Gen 4 or Gen 5. So we're seeing a number of quite a few orders of upgrades of factories in that
componenttext: Well, traditionally, OLED has been for smaller form factor experience for smartphones, cell phones and those kind of applications, so most of the factories are Gen 4 or Gen 5. So we're seeing a number of quite a few orders of upgrades of factories in that space. There's one major panel manufacturer that's making a much larger factory for OLEDs for TVs. So that's really the beginning of getting a large-size glass onto OLED. So that's the big exciting opportunity, along with some other upgrade businesses to the smaller size factories.
