headline: Applied Materials Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 17, 2010
componenttextpreview: I guess within that, on the WFE plus or minus 10% for fiscal '11, can you talk a little bit about what kind of expected linearity you see throughout the year?
componenttext: I guess within that, on the WFE plus or minus 10% for fiscal '11, can you talk a little bit about what kind of expected linearity you see throughout the year?

headline: Applied Materials Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 17, 2010
componenttextpreview: Well, I think we have pretty good visibility of the Q1, C.J. But I think the things to look for, and I'll just tell you how we're looking at it and kind of the indicators we're looking at, the first one really is PCs. PCs still drive a huge amount of the
componenttext: Well, I think we have pretty good visibility of the Q1, C.J. But I think the things to look for, and I'll just tell you how we're looking at it and kind of the indicators we're looking at, the first one really is PCs. PCs still drive a huge amount of the DRAM capacity. We kind of targeted our view of flat WFE at about a 7% growth in PCs. And the percent growth versus percent of WFE is almost a 1:1 kind of relationship. So if PCs were up in the 10% to 15% range, we'd expect WFE to be up. The other thing we're really looking closely at is tablets, because tablets and smartphones drive NAND spending. We're expecting 50 million tablets and 350 million or 400 million smartphones. That's kind of our flat scenario, more than that would drive higher wafer fab equipment spending. As George talked about, we think Q1 SSG will be pretty strong modestly, flat to up. So that kind of tells you how we see the start of the year, at least January start of the year, in WFE.

headline: Applied Materials Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 17, 2010
componenttextpreview: And as a quick follow-up, considering kind of the ranges you expect across divisions, what kind of gross margin profile should we expect relative to the 42% you printed in fiscal '10?
componenttext: And as a quick follow-up, considering kind of the ranges you expect across divisions, what kind of gross margin profile should we expect relative to the 42% you printed in fiscal '10?

headline: Applied Materials Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 17, 2010
componenttextpreview: I think the way to think about gross margin is we've obviously had a lot of noise in it in both '09 from just the environment, and '10 from the restructuring of EES. We said that we would have been up two points, so in the 44-plus percent range this quart
componenttext: I think the way to think about gross margin is we've obviously had a lot of noise in it in both '09 from just the environment, and '10 from the restructuring of EES. We said that we would have been up two points, so in the 44-plus percent range this quarter if we had not had the SunFab sign up. That's probably a reasonable starting point, and then it will be a mix effect from there on.

headline: Applied Materials Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 17, 2010
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from Atif Malik with Morgan Stanley.
componenttext: Your next question comes from Atif Malik with Morgan Stanley.

headline: Applied Materials Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 17, 2010
componenttextpreview: My question is on the services side. George, you guys are doing quite well in terms of operating margins in other segments and kind of exceeding your prior peak levels in 2007. But on services, you mentioned there are some supply chain issues on 200-milli
componenttext: My question is on the services side. George, you guys are doing quite well in terms of operating margins in other segments and kind of exceeding your prior peak levels in 2007. But on services, you mentioned there are some supply chain issues on 200-millimeter. So as we see your sales growing 10% to 15% next year, can you help us understand where the operating margins for that business could be next year?

headline: Applied Materials Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 17, 2010
componenttextpreview: Sure. Obviously, we improved somewhat this quarter over the previous quarter, but we're still well behind where we want to be in terms of our operating model for the second half of 2011. We're still though working with a cold supply chain and incurring re
componenttext: Sure. Obviously, we improved somewhat this quarter over the previous quarter, but we're still well behind where we want to be in terms of our operating model for the second half of 2011. We're still though working with a cold supply chain and incurring relatively significant additional costs to support our customers. So we think it's going to take another quarter or two to get through this issue, and then you should start seeing three to four points or more of operating margin pick up with the same level of revenue.

headline: Applied Materials Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 17, 2010
componenttextpreview: And a quick follow-up, on the $600 million revenue that you expect from two percentage points of share gain in the Silicon segment, can you help us understand how much of that is being NAND driven, as the devices move to 3x nanometer and new Applied benef
componenttext: And a quick follow-up, on the $600 million revenue that you expect from two percentage points of share gain in the Silicon segment, can you help us understand how much of that is being NAND driven, as the devices move to 3x nanometer and new Applied benefit for how much that position for our product portfolio there? So how much of the $600 million are from NAND contribution?

headline: Applied Materials Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 17, 2010
componenttextpreview: That's a pretty hard question to answer, Atif. I think the way we're looking at this is in the scenario -- because you can do a million scenarios. But as I said, we're expecting flash to be about $6 billion, let's say out of the $30 billion. So DRAM is al
componenttext: That's a pretty hard question to answer, Atif. I think the way we're looking at this is in the scenario -- because you can do a million scenarios. But as I said, we're expecting flash to be about $6 billion, let's say out of the $30 billion. So DRAM is almost the same. We're expecting foundry to be up a bit. So our specific share in flash is off our average WFE share, but our specific share in foundry is above our WFE shares. So these things kind of balance out overall.

headline: Applied Materials Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 17, 2010
componenttextpreview: Also, the 2% related to 2010, that reflects the mix of business that we saw, which was lighter in NAND overall than we would expect to see in 2011.
componenttext: Also, the 2% related to 2010, that reflects the mix of business that we saw, which was lighter in NAND overall than we would expect to see in 2011.

headline: Applied Materials Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 17, 2010
componenttextpreview: But we do expect to gain more than a point of share versus WFE in 2011, which would be two points or more than two points in our markets.
componenttext: But we do expect to gain more than a point of share versus WFE in 2011, which would be two points or more than two points in our markets.

headline: Applied Materials Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 17, 2010
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from Jim Covello with Goldman Sachs.
componenttext: Your next question comes from Jim Covello with Goldman Sachs.

headline: Applied Materials Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 17, 2010
componenttextpreview: So when you talk about NAND ramping in the second half of next year, I mean, can you talk a little bit about the dynamic there of -- do you think the existing NAND capacity can satisfy the early part of the tablet ramp as we go through next year, and then
componenttext: So when you talk about NAND ramping in the second half of next year, I mean, can you talk a little bit about the dynamic there of -- do you think the existing NAND capacity can satisfy the early part of the tablet ramp as we go through next year, and then its incremental tablets to driving that incremental NAND spend? Or if you could talk a little about the dynamics on that, that would be great.

headline: Applied Materials Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 17, 2010
componenttextpreview: Well, we just think second half will be greater than the first half. It's not that there isn't investment in the first half. But in particular, we think we'll see the major part of a major factory in Japan ramping up in the second half. So that's really t
componenttext: Well, we just think second half will be greater than the first half. It's not that there isn't investment in the first half. But in particular, we think we'll see the major part of a major factory in Japan ramping up in the second half. So that's really the major effect there. But other additions will happen, as a matter of course in the first half of the year. In 2010, flash spending was $4 billion, so we'll certainly see that kind of run rate pretty much continue and grow through the year.

headline: Applied Materials Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 17, 2010
componenttextpreview: I see. And so could you see orders ramping over the next few quarters and then it's the shipments that ramp in the latter part of next year? Is that the idea?
componenttext: I see. And so could you see orders ramping over the next few quarters and then it's the shipments that ramp in the latter part of next year? Is that the idea?

headline: Applied Materials Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 17, 2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, that's the idea.
componenttext: Yes, that's the idea.

headline: Applied Materials Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 17, 2010
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from Satya Kumar with Crédit Suisse.
componenttext: Your next question comes from Satya Kumar with Crédit Suisse.

headline: Applied Materials Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 17, 2010
componenttextpreview: Just a quick question on the Solar side, you have seen a significant ramp in orders from Q1 to Q4 for Solar and you're talking about a 12 to 14 gigawatt new capacity additions for the whole year. If I look at Q4 alone, is it fair to say that on a run rate
componenttext: Just a quick question on the Solar side, you have seen a significant ramp in orders from Q1 to Q4 for Solar and you're talking about a 12 to 14 gigawatt new capacity additions for the whole year. If I look at Q4 alone, is it fair to say that on a run rate basis, the new capacity additions are approaching the 18 to 20 gigawatt run rate?

headline: Applied Materials Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 17, 2010
componenttextpreview: I think that's fair, yes, on a run rate basis.
componenttext: I think that's fair, yes, on a run rate basis.

headline: Applied Materials Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 17, 2010
componenttextpreview: In the last conference call, I think you were sounding a little bit more cautious on the sustainability of this type of new capacity additions, but it appears that you're looking at a similar capacity addition run rate for fiscal 2011. I was wondering wha
componenttext: In the last conference call, I think you were sounding a little bit more cautious on the sustainability of this type of new capacity additions, but it appears that you're looking at a similar capacity addition run rate for fiscal 2011. I was wondering what trend you are seeing in the customer base that makes you believe that this trend can continue? I think you even mentioned that fiscal Q1 looks better than fiscal Q4.

headline: Applied Materials Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 17, 2010
componenttextpreview: Well, that's obviously the number one trend that our customers have confidence to continue to invest and invest strongly in capacity. And many of the bigger guys are fully loaded and sold out for some extended period of time. So they are adding capacity a
componenttext: Well, that's obviously the number one trend that our customers have confidence to continue to invest and invest strongly in capacity. And many of the bigger guys are fully loaded and sold out for some extended period of time. So they are adding capacity and haven't slowed down a bit. As a retrospective, as I thought about how I felt a year ago, the situation was kind of the same. The business was strong. It was continuing to go up. And I think we haven't seen the peak yet in Solar. And despite feed-in tariffs continuing to go down, they seem to just spur more investment as the pricing continues to get driven down. I think pricing for modules and installations is going to continue to go down, which will continue to make it like look like a very solid investment.

headline: Applied Materials Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 17, 2010
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from Stephen Chin with UBS.
componenttext: Your next question comes from Stephen Chin with UBS.

headline: Applied Materials Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 17, 2010
componenttextpreview: Just a question on the January quarter silicon sales guidance, I think you said it would be flat to up slightly sequentially. My question is that the silicon backlog was up another 21% sequentially in this October quarter, so you might argue that the Janu
componenttext: Just a question on the January quarter silicon sales guidance, I think you said it would be flat to up slightly sequentially. My question is that the silicon backlog was up another 21% sequentially in this October quarter, so you might argue that the January sales guidance could be conservative. Is it conservative just on a maybe less turns business in the Silicon Systems business in the January quarter?

headline: Applied Materials Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 17, 2010
componenttextpreview: No, I think, clearly we've seen a fair amount of turns business. But you can get pushes and pulls.  Certainly we're seeing, with where DRAM pricing is, you got the holiday season coming up. You got a lot of factors that can cause customers to move things
componenttext: No, I think, clearly we've seen a fair amount of turns business. But you can get pushes and pulls.  Certainly we're seeing, with where DRAM pricing is, you got the holiday season coming up. You got a lot of factors that can cause customers to move things around. We think with the visibility that we have today, we're comfortable with the flat. That's why we said we kind of see the risk and reward balanced for the quarter. And there's certainly scenarios where it could be up. But that's a pretty concentrated group of customers, so it could also be down if somebody pushes out. Right now, we feel good about the forecast.

headline: Applied Materials Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 17, 2010
componenttextpreview: Maybe I can ask a different question on the EES operating margin. I was wondering, George, maybe you could share any color on what the normalized operating margin of just the Crystalline Systems business might be since those figures are executing well the
componenttext: Maybe I can ask a different question on the EES operating margin. I was wondering, George, maybe you could share any color on what the normalized operating margin of just the Crystalline Systems business might be since those figures are executing well there. And if you don't want to share the number, is it closer to the silicon margins? Or is it closer to the Display margins? Just trying to get a sense of what this could look like going forward once the SunFab revenue recognition stops.

headline: Applied Materials Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 17, 2010
componenttextpreview: Well, what we've said is we gave a model in July that gave an indication of what it looks like post. And our model was intentionally conservative coming out. So we've said better than 10% operating margins at $1.250 billion quarter run rate. And obviously
componenttext: Well, what we've said is we gave a model in July that gave an indication of what it looks like post. And our model was intentionally conservative coming out. So we've said better than 10% operating margins at $1.250 billion quarter run rate. And obviously, we had a pretty strong quarter this quarter. I think we can do better than the operating model, and we'll continue to watch that through the year. As you know, this business can be volatile. And right now, it looks very strong in the first half of the year, and so we'll just have to see how the second half of the year. But we feel very good overall. And if you kind of compare year-over-year, where we had a significant loss in the EES area, we're going to have a high confidence on our profit this year. That's going to be a big swing year-over-year for us.

headline: Applied Materials Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 17, 2010
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from Krish Sankar with Bank of America.
componenttext: Your next question comes from Krish Sankar with Bank of America.

headline: Applied Materials Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 17, 2010
componenttextpreview: Mike, you said that you expect NAND CapEx to be back half loaded. What is your view on how the foundry CapEx would trend through 2011?
componenttext: Mike, you said that you expect NAND CapEx to be back half loaded. What is your view on how the foundry CapEx would trend through 2011?

headline: Applied Materials Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 17, 2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, so we think foundry is going to be pretty strong throughout the year leading the way, even up in the first part of the year here a bit. But we think it will be up overall slightly over 2010 and pretty even through the year as the various players fill
componenttext: Yes, so we think foundry is going to be pretty strong throughout the year leading the way, even up in the first part of the year here a bit. But we think it will be up overall slightly over 2010 and pretty even through the year as the various players fill up their fabs.

headline: Applied Materials Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 17, 2010
componenttextpreview: And then a question for George. Given your of fiscal year 2011 guidance and keeping the composition of the revenue as what you said, what do you think would be the OpEx run rate exiting 2011?
componenttext: And then a question for George. Given your of fiscal year 2011 guidance and keeping the composition of the revenue as what you said, what do you think would be the OpEx run rate exiting 2011?

headline: Applied Materials Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 17, 2010
componenttextpreview: Well, what we said is we're going -- the first half of the year, we think the OpEx run rate will be somewhere between $500 million and $520 million. I think we'll just have to see how the second half plays out. We've got a fairly strong variable model as
componenttext: Well, what we said is we're going -- the first half of the year, we think the OpEx run rate will be somewhere between $500 million and $520 million. I think we'll just have to see how the second half plays out. We've got a fairly strong variable model as you know. If we see strength in the second of the year, then I think that's probably a good continuing estimate. But it'll get a little bit of help just because we'll continue to have finish up the restructuring of EES over that time period. And if, for some reason, the year is down, we'll be able to take OpEx down a little bit with it.

headline: Applied Materials Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 17, 2010
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from Peter Kim with Deutsche Bank.
componenttext: Your next question comes from Peter Kim with Deutsche Bank.

headline: Applied Materials Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 17, 2010
componenttextpreview: So the question I wanted to ask about was the EES portion. The crystalline silicon sales in fiscal 2011 to be, just the Silicon segment alone, will be up year-over-year or slightly down?
componenttext: So the question I wanted to ask about was the EES portion. The crystalline silicon sales in fiscal 2011 to be, just the Silicon segment alone, will be up year-over-year or slightly down?

headline: Applied Materials Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 17, 2010
componenttextpreview: For just the crystalline sales?
componenttext: For just the crystalline sales?

headline: Applied Materials Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 17, 2010
componenttextpreview: That's correct.
componenttext: That's correct.

headline: Applied Materials Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 17, 2010
componenttextpreview: We believe they'll be up year-over-year.
componenttext: We believe they'll be up year-over-year.

headline: Applied Materials Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 17, 2010
componenttextpreview: And you expect that to operate at near 10% to 14% operating margins?
componenttext: And you expect that to operate at near 10% to 14% operating margins?

headline: Applied Materials Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 17, 2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, definitely better than 10%.
componenttext: Yes, definitely better than 10%.

headline: Applied Materials Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 17, 2010
componenttextpreview: With regards to the 200-millimeter, I mean, it's definitely been very strong for you in the past couple of quarters. I was wondering how long you think that trend could continue? Do you expect that the demand for 200-millimeter to continue to improve year
componenttext: With regards to the 200-millimeter, I mean, it's definitely been very strong for you in the past couple of quarters. I was wondering how long you think that trend could continue? Do you expect that the demand for 200-millimeter to continue to improve year-over-year? Or do you expect that at some point the 200-millimeter capacity could start to slow down?

headline: Applied Materials Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 17, 2010
componenttextpreview: We think right now we're in a bit of a surge on 200-millimeter capacity because there was so much taken off in 2009. And for MEMS, for power transistors, for solar panels and electric cars, for analog devices or for things like display drivers all need 20
componenttext: We think right now we're in a bit of a surge on 200-millimeter capacity because there was so much taken off in 2009. And for MEMS, for power transistors, for solar panels and electric cars, for analog devices or for things like display drivers all need 200-millimeter, so we think that the market will peak here sometime in 2011 and then come back down to some steady state rate that's maybe off the peak we'll see in the next few quarters by 10% or 20%, something on that order.

headline: Applied Materials Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 17, 2010
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from Gary Hsueh with Oppenheimer & Co.
componenttext: Your next question comes from Gary Hsueh with Oppenheimer & Co.

headline: Applied Materials Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 17, 2010
componenttextpreview: Mike, I understand that heading into 2011, there's a lot of uncertainties and flat year-over-year kind of spending environment, sort of a non-committal sort of forecast for 2011. But if you took your SSG kind of guidance for Q1, and let's say flatlined it
componenttext: Mike, I understand that heading into 2011, there's a lot of uncertainties and flat year-over-year kind of spending environment, sort of a non-committal sort of forecast for 2011. But if you took your SSG kind of guidance for Q1, and let's say flatlined it throughout the year, you're looking at a fiscal 2011 that's up well above 10%, let's say more around 15%. So I'm just wondering where do you think the potential pitfalls are in terms of the SSG business, either near term or in the back half of 2011? And my second question is if we're looking at a NAND-heavy spending environment in 2011, I'm wondering if you could kind of take a quick stab at how well you guys could outperform the market in SSG given increasing market share, as you pointed out, and maybe just natural market share being higher for some of these NAND manufacturers?

headline: Applied Materials Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 17, 2010
componenttextpreview: So, yes, if the entire year was like you want, it would be up quite a bit more than 10%. It's just we're in a bit of an uncertain environment. And the big deal in my mind on this, the big pitfall or potential upside is all around DRAM and PC-related deman
componenttext: So, yes, if the entire year was like you want, it would be up quite a bit more than 10%. It's just we're in a bit of an uncertain environment. And the big deal in my mind on this, the big pitfall or potential upside is all around DRAM and PC-related demand. So we feel like relative to -- we feel we're pretty much on the industry consensus between 5% and 10% in our estimate, but there's obviously been a lot of discussion of bigger numbers from people who know this business well, like Intel and AMD. So if WFE stays as strong as it is at the beginning of the year, we'll have a stronger year. But the market is volatile, and it's hard to predict we'll hit 10%, I think. That's the key area and potential pitfall. Our estimate on our share growth is based on both foundry and NAND going up kind of together. We're excited in particular about etch gains in flash memory, that should be a big positive for us, deposition gains of course, as double patterning becomes a bigger part of the process. And one of the areas in 2010 that positively surprised us I think from the beginning of the year was our CMP position. We won a lot of share back in CMP. We have a great new product there, Reflexion GT that improves productivity as being adopted. And of course, I did want to say that rare earth element constraints in the market are not going to slow down CMP, at least we don't think so. But anyway, that's kind of the picture. I'm not sure I answered all your questions, but maybe you do have a quick follow-up.

headline: Applied Materials Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 17, 2010
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from Patrick Ho with Stifel, Nicolaus.
componenttext: Your next question comes from Patrick Ho with Stifel, Nicolaus.

headline: Applied Materials Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 17, 2010
componenttextpreview: Mike, following off that last question about the market share gains, you mentioned double patterning as being one of the key application drivers for the share wins. Can you just comment, I guess broadly, what other, I guess, process changes or other appli
componenttext: Mike, following off that last question about the market share gains, you mentioned double patterning as being one of the key application drivers for the share wins. Can you just comment, I guess broadly, what other, I guess, process changes or other applications that will help you gain share both this year and into next year?

headline: Applied Materials Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 17, 2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, I'd say really three things. One is the conversion to metal gate at the logic and foundry companies. This has helped our PVD business substantially. The second one is conversion to copper in the memory companies. Semitool has done very well in that m
componenttext: Yes, I'd say really three things. One is the conversion to metal gate at the logic and foundry companies. This has helped our PVD business substantially. The second one is conversion to copper in the memory companies. Semitool has done very well in that market, certainly won more than their standard share by a wide margin. And then the third area is the movement towards wafer-level packaging where we've been able to put together a suite of products there that really help the customers see how the integration of the various processes go together. And we're quite bullish. We kind of added up all the wins in that space over the year. And there were some -- we won basically over 60% of those decisions in our market, so I think there was some 65 decisions across the industry that we counted up this year. So while that market isn't big yet, it really, I think, is a harbinger for positive future for our SSG products.

headline: Applied Materials Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 17, 2010
componenttextpreview: And my follow-up question is kind of longer term and bigger picture. Your flowable CVD product, I think you mentioned when the product was introduced, it's something that's targeting the 2x nanometer and below and it's a $400 million opportunity. Is that
componenttext: And my follow-up question is kind of longer term and bigger picture. Your flowable CVD product, I think you mentioned when the product was introduced, it's something that's targeting the 2x nanometer and below and it's a $400 million opportunity. Is that something that's still 2012 and beyond where you are targeting? Or do you see any kind of accelerations or pull-ins into 2011 as you work with your customers?

headline: Applied Materials Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 17, 2010
componenttextpreview: Well, we were think it's the secret to really a small, narrow STI [Shallow Trench Isolation] and to multi-cell performance in flash. So we're starting to see more and more interest in that product. Customers have had to do some extremely difficult integra
componenttext: Well, we were think it's the secret to really a small, narrow STI [Shallow Trench Isolation] and to multi-cell performance in flash. So we're starting to see more and more interest in that product. Customers have had to do some extremely difficult integration schemes with spin-on and CVD depositions to fill those narrow gaps. With this product, you can get away from a lot of that complexity and cost. So there's a lot of interest there. It's too early to say it's a big pull-in into 2011, but we certainly see it being an important product, certainly for DRAM, for flash and getting into logic as well.

headline: Applied Materials Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 17, 2010
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from Timothy Arcuri with Citi.
componenttext: Your next question comes from Timothy Arcuri with Citi.

headline: Applied Materials Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 17, 2010
componenttextpreview: First of all, if I look at your SSG business, you overbooked what you revenued in July, and you overbooked what you revenued in October as well. So if revenue was flat in January, it would seem to imply that bookings and sort of SSG are going to be down s
componenttext: First of all, if I look at your SSG business, you overbooked what you revenued in July, and you overbooked what you revenued in October as well. So if revenue was flat in January, it would seem to imply that bookings and sort of SSG are going to be down something like 20%? Is that sort of right math?

headline: Applied Materials Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 17, 2010
componenttextpreview: No, I do think we're thinking that at all. No.
componenttext: No, I do think we're thinking that at all. No.

headline: Applied Materials Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 17, 2010
componenttextpreview: No, I think it really reflects the combination of starting with a very low backlog and a high turns business.
componenttext: No, I think it really reflects the combination of starting with a very low backlog and a high turns business.

headline: Applied Materials Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 17, 2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, I think our order pattern has dramatically changed from history, Tim. And to read too much into what's in the bookings backlog for SSG is more about who's ordering than the order magnitude itself.
componenttext: Yes, I think our order pattern has dramatically changed from history, Tim. And to read too much into what's in the bookings backlog for SSG is more about who's ordering than the order magnitude itself.

headline: Applied Materials Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 17, 2010
componenttextpreview: So just on that point, so Mike, are you saying that customers are ordering, placing orders now for deliveries like in the second of next year, is that what you're saying?
componenttext: So just on that point, so Mike, are you saying that customers are ordering, placing orders now for deliveries like in the second of next year, is that what you're saying?

headline: Applied Materials Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 17, 2010
componenttextpreview: Other way around. They're ordering now for deliveries in this quarter.
componenttext: Other way around. They're ordering now for deliveries in this quarter.

headline: Applied Materials Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 17, 2010
componenttextpreview: So if that was the case, then you're booking should sort of more closely match your shipments, right?
componenttext: So if that was the case, then you're booking should sort of more closely match your shipments, right?

headline: Applied Materials Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 17, 2010
componenttextpreview: I think you've been ramping revenues significantly coming out of '09, and you've had the turns business combined. And it's highly concentrated in a couple of customers. I mean, the turns business is effectively a process where with a few customers, they d
componenttext: I think you've been ramping revenues significantly coming out of '09, and you've had the turns business combined. And it's highly concentrated in a couple of customers. I mean, the turns business is effectively a process where with a few customers, they don't walk down the POs but you've had a lot dialogue, a lot of scheduling, a lot of product configuration. It's just that the way the process, you don't close the traditional order until the quarter in which they shift. And as you know, we've had a far more concentrated customer base and so you get some of these patterns that you are looking for.

headline: Applied Materials Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 17, 2010
componenttextpreview: Just on the model in of AGS. Before, you had said something like 24% to 26% operating margin at the $2 billion revenue run rate. And it seems like you're 400 to 500 basis points below that model. Is that just sort of a catch-up that we'll see next year or
componenttext: Just on the model in of AGS. Before, you had said something like 24% to 26% operating margin at the $2 billion revenue run rate. And it seems like you're 400 to 500 basis points below that model. Is that just sort of a catch-up that we'll see next year or is there something going on in AGS that's sort of causing you to be shy of that model?

headline: Applied Materials Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 17, 2010
componenttextpreview: No, as we've said, we're shy of where we should be against the model because of the 200-millimeter shipment issues that we're having at really all out of the supply chain. So I agree, we're operating at least a three to four points, maybe three points tod
componenttext: No, as we've said, we're shy of where we should be against the model because of the 200-millimeter shipment issues that we're having at really all out of the supply chain. So I agree, we're operating at least a three to four points, maybe three points today below where I'd like to see us, and then that widens out a little bit by the end of next year where we said we would have flown through a lot of the kind of transformational restructuring activities in AGS. So you would see the full model in place. We said we're not at the second half of '11 yet where we said all those models will be in place. But we're not where we would like to be right now there, and we're working on it.

headline: Applied Materials Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 17, 2010
componenttextpreview: So our next question comes from Edwin Mok with Needman (sic) [Needham & Company].
componenttext: So our next question comes from Edwin Mok with Needman (sic) [Needham & Company].

headline: Applied Materials Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 17, 2010
componenttextpreview: So just a question on your orders that you print, I noticed that the orders from the kind of logic/auto customer has constantly high-level, probably one of the highest historically. Can I ask why that's the case? Is that tied to more 200-millimeter or is
componenttext: So just a question on your orders that you print, I noticed that the orders from the kind of logic/auto customer has constantly high-level, probably one of the highest historically. Can I ask why that's the case? Is that tied to more 200-millimeter or is there some specific customer order?

headline: Applied Materials Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 17, 2010
componenttextpreview: Primarily one large logic customer that's placing a number of orders, yes.
componenttext: Primarily one large logic customer that's placing a number of orders, yes.

headline: Applied Materials Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 17, 2010
componenttextpreview: Then I have a follow-up question on your Display business. You mentioned that you guys have a new product, the PVD product, you mentioned share gain in that area. Baking into your full year guidance of Display down 20% to 25%, that's roughly in line with
componenttext: Then I have a follow-up question on your Display business. You mentioned that you guys have a new product, the PVD product, you mentioned share gain in that area. Baking into your full year guidance of Display down 20% to 25%, that's roughly in line with what you said will be their end market, are you proud to think that there's limit room to gain further share on PVD? Or am I reading too much into that guidance versus your own business?

headline: Applied Materials Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 17, 2010
componenttextpreview: I think you're reading too much into the guidance. I said we think Display will be down, the market will be down more than 20%. And we were talking specifically about our guidance for 2011, the 20% to 25%. So I wouldn't read into it. We think we've got a
componenttext: I think you're reading too much into the guidance. I said we think Display will be down, the market will be down more than 20%. And we were talking specifically about our guidance for 2011, the 20% to 25%. So I wouldn't read into it. We think we've got a good PVD product. It's going to continue to gain share, and we would expect to hold share in our other major products at a minimum.

headline: Applied Materials Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 17, 2010
componenttextpreview: And we have opportunity ahead with touch panels and OLEDs as another positive trend there. And we're just reacting to the weak TV market that we've been seeing recently.
componenttext: And we have opportunity ahead with touch panels and OLEDs as another positive trend there. And we're just reacting to the weak TV market that we've been seeing recently.

headline: Applied Materials Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 17, 2010
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from Mehdi Hosseini with Susquehanna International.
componenttext: Your next question comes from Mehdi Hosseini with Susquehanna International.

headline: Applied Materials Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 17, 2010
componenttextpreview: Mike, I'm a little bit confused. In your prepared remarks, you said NAND spending is going to be about $6 billion or even higher than that. And then that's going to be higher than DRAM CapEx next year?
componenttext: Mike, I'm a little bit confused. In your prepared remarks, you said NAND spending is going to be about $6 billion or even higher than that. And then that's going to be higher than DRAM CapEx next year?

headline: Applied Materials Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 17, 2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, potentially it'll be higher than the DRAM CapEx, which we think be off a bit from where it is, just slightly lower than flash.
componenttext: Yes, potentially it'll be higher than the DRAM CapEx, which we think be off a bit from where it is, just slightly lower than flash.

headline: Applied Materials Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 17, 2010
componenttextpreview: So if DRAM is going to be less than $6 billion and you're suggesting that WFE is going to be flat, then where will the $5 billion, $6 billion, $10 billion decline in DRAM spending going to be offset from?
componenttext: So if DRAM is going to be less than $6 billion and you're suggesting that WFE is going to be flat, then where will the $5 billion, $6 billion, $10 billion decline in DRAM spending going to be offset from?

headline: Applied Materials Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 17, 2010
componenttextpreview: I'll just give you the numbers we're working with so that we avoid the confusion. We think DRAM spent $8.5 billion in 2010. We think it'll be down to roughly $6 billion. NAND spent $4 billion dollars in 2010 and will be up to over $6 billion. So those two
componenttext: I'll just give you the numbers we're working with so that we avoid the confusion. We think DRAM spent $8.5 billion in 2010. We think it'll be down to roughly $6 billion. NAND spent $4 billion dollars in 2010 and will be up to over $6 billion. So those two, on a gross basis pretty much balance out. And then we think foundry will be up to give a flat overall market.

headline: Applied Materials Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 17, 2010
componenttextpreview: And then just as a follow-up, where are we going to hear any update on the LED front?
componenttext: And then just as a follow-up, where are we going to hear any update on the LED front?

headline: Applied Materials Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 17, 2010
componenttextpreview: We're working with some key customers, and we're getting increased interest. But they're starting to really see the uniqueness of our product. And when that product has met all of its requirements, we'll introduce it, but not till then.
componenttext: We're working with some key customers, and we're getting increased interest. But they're starting to really see the uniqueness of our product. And when that product has met all of its requirements, we'll introduce it, but not till then.

headline: Applied Materials Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 17, 2010
componenttextpreview: Should I assume that this is a strategy by you to make sure that the product acceptance, penetration is in full force before coming out public? It's somewhat contrast to what happened to SunFab, or is it a reflection of maybe some challenges or longer-tha
componenttext: Should I assume that this is a strategy by you to make sure that the product acceptance, penetration is in full force before coming out public? It's somewhat contrast to what happened to SunFab, or is it a reflection of maybe some challenges or longer-than-expected acceptance?

headline: Applied Materials Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 17, 2010
componenttextpreview: No, I think we just want to make sure that the product is the product that we want. These products are complex, and process has to meet the requirements that customers have and provide uniqueness to garner its value in the marketplace. So I wouldn't read
componenttext: No, I think we just want to make sure that the product is the product that we want. These products are complex, and process has to meet the requirements that customers have and provide uniqueness to garner its value in the marketplace. So I wouldn't read a whole lot into it besides that.

headline: Applied Materials Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 17, 2010
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from Brian Lee with JPMorgan.
componenttext: Your next question comes from Brian Lee with JPMorgan.

headline: Applied Materials Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 17, 2010
componenttextpreview: I guess last quarter you provided guidance for the quarter but also some qualitative color around SSG shipments being up in fiscal Q1 versus Q4. Do you have that same level of visibility today to provide the same sort of qualitative color for fiscal Q2 re
componenttext: I guess last quarter you provided guidance for the quarter but also some qualitative color around SSG shipments being up in fiscal Q1 versus Q4. Do you have that same level of visibility today to provide the same sort of qualitative color for fiscal Q2 relative to Q1?

headline: Applied Materials Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 17, 2010
componenttextpreview: No, I think we had just such a very strong indication and a couple of projects where it was just very clear that we would have a strong Q1 that we went out and gave that picture. Also, we felt at that time there was some confusion about whether we would b
componenttext: No, I think we had just such a very strong indication and a couple of projects where it was just very clear that we would have a strong Q1 that we went out and gave that picture. Also, we felt at that time there was some confusion about whether we would be experiencing an immediate drop off, and we just didn't see that. So we don't have -- I'd say it's not a function of having no visibility for our fiscal Q2, but we're just going to stick with the Q1 guidance.

headline: Applied Materials Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 17, 2010
componenttextpreview: And then as a follow-up, I guess, on the operating margin for EES, I know you talked about the two-point impact to the overall gross margin from the SunFab sign-up. What would operating margin for EES have been in the quarter if we exclude the impact to S
componenttext: And then as a follow-up, I guess, on the operating margin for EES, I know you talked about the two-point impact to the overall gross margin from the SunFab sign-up. What would operating margin for EES have been in the quarter if we exclude the impact to SunFab?

headline: Applied Materials Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 17, 2010
componenttextpreview: I haven't broken that out, but the margin would have clearly been up relative to the 14% reported. It was a very, very strong quarter overall. So again, we're not breaking out the individual operating margins at that level. But again, we would expect anot
componenttext: I haven't broken that out, but the margin would have clearly been up relative to the 14% reported. It was a very, very strong quarter overall. So again, we're not breaking out the individual operating margins at that level. But again, we would expect another similarly strong quarter next quarter.

headline: Applied Materials Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 17, 2010
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from Mahesh Sanganeria with RBC Capital Markets.
componenttext: Your next question comes from Mahesh Sanganeria with RBC Capital Markets.

headline: Applied Materials Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 17, 2010

componenttext: George, you talked about $300 million in thin films revenue and you said you recognized $225 million to SunFab, is there some more, is there $74 million, $75 million more that you need to recognize in January quarter?

headline: Applied Materials Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 17, 2010
componenttextpreview: No, we have one remaining SunFab factory that's not signed off. It's very small, relatively speaking. We are talking to some of our existing SunFab customers about equipment to upgrade certain other facilities, but we haven't forecasted any of those proje
componenttext: No, we have one remaining SunFab factory that's not signed off. It's very small, relatively speaking. We are talking to some of our existing SunFab customers about equipment to upgrade certain other facilities, but we haven't forecasted any of those projects at this point.

headline: Applied Materials Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 17, 2010
componenttextpreview: And quickly, if I take your yearly guidance for EES and order you just reported, it looks like that it will be pretty linearly declining, first because of the impact of SunFab, but even crystalline looks like you need to decline a lot to get to your down
componenttext: And quickly, if I take your yearly guidance for EES and order you just reported, it looks like that it will be pretty linearly declining, first because of the impact of SunFab, but even crystalline looks like you need to decline a lot to get to your down 25%. And that would imply, if I keep backlog flattish, that will imply orders declined for 50% next quarter?

headline: Applied Materials Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 17, 2010
componenttextpreview: I think you probably have too low a number for thin film-related revenue, which was about $500 million last year. So if you make that adjustment, you'll see that at the low end it's kind of flat and then it comes up from there.
componenttext: I think you probably have too low a number for thin film-related revenue, which was about $500 million last year. So if you make that adjustment, you'll see that at the low end it's kind of flat and then it comes up from there.

componenttext: Your next question comes from Jagadish Iyer with Arete Research.

componenttext: First, I wanted to find out, you talked about the wafer-level packaging, I just wanted to understand how much has been the contribution this year from this particular share gains or wins? And what is your best estimate for '11 please?

componenttext: You mean on the versus wafer fab equipment?

componenttext: In 2010, very small. So 2011, I have to take a peek, but it'll be well over $100 million or more in 2011, could be as high as $300 million, depending on who ramps volume first.

headline: Applied Materials Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 17, 2010
componenttextpreview: Mike, this is the first time you talked about a little bit on the OLED equipment. Can you give us some color on what the offering is and how this market can grow potentially, please?
componenttext: Mike, this is the first time you talked about a little bit on the OLED equipment. Can you give us some color on what the offering is and how this market can grow potentially, please?

headline: Applied Materials Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 17, 2010
componenttextpreview: Well, traditionally, OLED has been for smaller form factor experience for smartphones, cell phones and those kind of applications, so most of the factories are Gen 4 or Gen 5. So we're seeing a number of quite a few orders of upgrades of factories in that
componenttext: Well, traditionally, OLED has been for smaller form factor experience for smartphones, cell phones and those kind of applications, so most of the factories are Gen 4 or Gen 5. So we're seeing a number of quite a few orders of upgrades of factories in that space. There's one major panel manufacturer that's making a much larger factory for OLEDs for TVs. So that's really the beginning of getting a large-size glass onto OLED. So that's the big exciting opportunity, along with some other upgrade businesses to the smaller size factories.

headline: Applied Materials Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 17, 2010
componenttextpreview: Your last question comes from Krish Sankar with Bank of America.
componenttext: Your last question comes from Krish Sankar with Bank of America.

headline: Applied Materials Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 17, 2010
componenttextpreview: You said 85% of the EES backlog was crystalline silicon. What is the remaining $125 million worth of completion of it?
componenttext: You said 85% of the EES backlog was crystalline silicon. What is the remaining $125 million worth of completion of it?

headline: Applied Materials Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 17, 2010
componenttextpreview: Sure. We've got web-related -- remember, in the statement, we also have our Web business, and we've had a fair amount of interest for roll-to-roll coating related, actually, both to packaging which has been the traditional and then also now increasingly f
componenttext: Sure. We've got web-related -- remember, in the statement, we also have our Web business, and we've had a fair amount of interest for roll-to-roll coating related, actually, both to packaging which has been the traditional and then also now increasingly for touchscreen applications for what we would call our SmartWeb products. We also have some, again, a minor backlog related to one small SunFab factory to sign off, and that covers 90% of what we're talking about.

headline: Applied Materials Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 17, 2010
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Carrie. And we'd like to thank everyone for joining us this afternoon. Our earnings slide package is now available on our website, and a replay of this call is going to be available by about 5:00 p.m. Pacific Time. And both of these items are goin
componenttext: Thanks, Carrie. And we'd like to thank everyone for joining us this afternoon. Our earnings slide package is now available on our website, and a replay of this call is going to be available by about 5:00 p.m. Pacific Time. And both of these items are going to remain available until December 1. We'd like to thank you for your continued interest in Applied Materials.
